for using outlook web access (owa)&#10;&#10;1. once your mailbox has been migrated from notes to outlook, the outlook &#10;client will be configured on your computer.&#10;after migration of your mailbox, you will not be able to send or recieve mail &#10;via notes, and you will not be able to start using outlook until it is &#10;configured by the outlook migration team the morning after your mailbox is &#10;migrated. during this period, you can use outlook web access (owa) via your &#10;web browser (internet explorer 5.0) to read and send mail.&#10;&#10;please note: your calendar entries, personal address book, journals, and &#10;to-do entries imported from notes will not be available until the outlook &#10;client is configured on your desktop.&#10;&#10;2. remote access to your mailbox.&#10;after your outlook client is configured, you can use outlook web access (owa) &#10;for remote access to your mailbox.&#10;&#10;please note: at this time, the owa client is only accessible while &#10;connecting to the enron network (lan). there are future plans to make owa &#10;available from your home or when traveling abroad.&#10;&#10;how to access outlook web access (owa)&#10;&#10;launch internet explorer 5.0, and in the address window type: &#10;http://nahou-msowa01p/exchange/john.doe&#10;&#10;substitute &quot;john.doe&quot; with your first and last name, then click enter. you &#10;will be prompted with a sign in box as shown below. type in &quot;corp/your user &#10;id&quot; for the user name and your nt password to logon to owa and click ok. you &#10;will now be able to view your mailbox.&#10;&#10; &#10;&#10;please note: there are some subtle differences in the functionality between &#10;the outlook and owa clients. you will not be able to do many of the things &#10;in owa that you can do in outlook. below is a brief list of *some* of the &#10;functions not available via owa:&#10;&#10;features not available using owa:&#10;&#10;- tasks&#10;- journal&#10;- spell checker&#10;- offline use&#10;- printing templates&#10;- reminders&#10;- timed delivery&#10;- expiration&#10;- outlook rules&#10;- voting, message flags and message recall&#10;- sharing contacts with others&#10;- task delegation&#10;- direct resource booking&#10;- personal distribution lists&#10;&#10;questions or concerns?&#10;&#10;if you have questions or concerns using the owa client, please contact the &#10;outlook 2000 question and answer mailbox at:&#10;&#10; outlook.2000@enron.com&#10;&#10;otherwise, you may contact the resolution center at:&#10;&#10; 713-853-1411&#10;&#10;thank you,&#10;&#10;outlook 2000 migration team&#10;</body></mail>

shortages&#10;competitive choices for consumers is the right answer&#10;any solution, however short term, that does not increase supply or reduce &#10;demand, is not acceptable&#10;eight out of eleven western governors oppose price caps, in that they would &#10;export california&apos;s problems to the west&#10;&#10;this is the latest intelligence i have on the matter, and it&apos;s a pretty &#10;strong anti- price cap position. of course, hebert is just one commissioner &#10;out of 3 currently on the commission, but he controls the meeting agenda and &#10;if the draft order is not to his 349:<mail><row>349</row><date>2001/04/10</date><from>phillip.allen@enron.com</from><to>mike.grigsby@enron.com</to><subj>caiso demand reduction</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>---------------------- forwarded by phillip k allen/hou/ect on 04/10/2001 &#10;05:50 pm ---------------------------&#10; &#10; enron north america corp.&#10; &#10; from: stephen swain 04/10/2001 11:58 am&#10; &#10;&#10;to: phillip k allen/hou/ect@ect&#10;cc: tim heizenrader/pdx/ect@ect, tim belden/hou/ect@ect, matt &#10;motley/pdx/ect@ect, michael m driscoll/pdx/ect@ect, chris &#10;mallory/pdx/ect@ect, jeff richter/hou/ect@ect, robert badeer/hou/ect@ect, &#10;sean crandall/pdx/ect@ect, mark fischer/pdx/ect@ect, bill williams &#10;iii/pdx/ect@ect, diana scholtes/hou/ect@ect &#10;subject: caiso demand reduction&#10;&#10;phillip et al.,&#10;&#10;i have been digging into the answer to your question re: demand reduction in &#10;the west. your intuition as to reductions seen so far (e.g., march 2001 vs. &#10;march 2000) was absolutely correct. at this point, it appears that demand &#10;over the last 12 months in the caiso control area, after adjusting for &#10;temperature and time of use factors, has fallen by about 6%. this translates &#10;into a reduction of about 1,500-1,600 mwa for last month (march 2001) as &#10;compared with the previous year.&#10;&#10;looking forward into the summer, i believe that we will see further voluntary &#10;reductions (as opposed to &quot;forced&quot; reductions via rolling blackouts). other &#10;forecasters (e.g., pira) are estimating that another 1,200-1,300 mwa (making &#10;total year-on-year reduction = 2,700-2,800) will come off starting in june. &#10;this scenario is not difficult to imagine, as it would require only a couple &#10;more percentage points reduction in overall peak demand. given that the 6% &#10;decrease we have seen so far has come without any real price signals to the &#10;retail market, and that rates are now scheduled to increase, i think that it &#10;is possible we could see peak demand fall by as much as 10% relative to last &#10;year. this would mean peak demand reductions of approx 3,300-3,500 mwa in &#10;jun-aug. in addition, a number of efforts aimed specifically at conservation &#10;are being promoted by the state, which can only increase the likelihood of &#10;meeting, and perhaps exceeding, the 3,500 mwa figure. finally, the general &#10;economic slowdown in calif could also further depress demand, or at least &#10;make the 3,500 mwa number that much more attainable.&#10;&#10;note that all the numbers i am reporting here are for the caiso control area &#10;only, which represents about 89% of total calif load, or 36-37% of wscc &#10;(u.s.) summer load. i think it is reasonable to assume that the non-iso &#10;portion of calif (i.e., ladwp and iid) will see similar reductions in &#10;demand. as for the rest of the wscc, that is a much more difficult call. as &#10;you are aware, the pacific nw has already seen about 2,000 mwa of aluminum &#10;smelter load come off since dec, and this load is expected to stay off at &#10;least through sep, and possibly for the next couple of years (if bpa gets its &#10;wish). this figure represents approx 4% of the non-calif wscc. several &#10;mining operations in the sw and rockies have recently announced that they are &#10;sharply curtailing production. i have not yet been able to pin down exactly &#10;how many mw this translates to, but i will continue to research the issue. &#10;other large industrials may follow suit, and the ripple effects from calif&apos;s &#10;economic slowdown could be a factor throughout the west. while the rest of &#10;the wscc may not see the 10%+ reductions that i am expecting in calif, i &#10;think we could easily expect an additional 2-3% (on top of the 4% already &#10;realized), or approx 1,000-1,500 mwa, of further demand reduction in the &#10;non-calif wscc for this summer. this would bring the total reduction for the &#10;wscc, including the 2,000 mwa aluminum load we have already seen, to around &#10;6,500-7,000 mwa when compared with last summer.&#10;&#10;i am continuing to research and monitor the situation, and will provide you &#10;with updates as new or better information becomes available. meantime, i &#10;hope this helps. please feel free to call (503-464-8671) if you have any &#10;questions or need any further information.&#10;</body></mail>

plants&#10;&#10;&#10;13:18 gmt 7 december 2000 dj cal-iso pays $10m to avoid rolling blackouts&#10;wed -sources&#10;(this article was originally published wednesday)&#10;los angeles (dow jones)--the california independent system operator paid&#10;about $10 million wednesday for 1,000 megawatts of power from powerex and&#10;still faced a massive deficit that threatened electricity reliability in the&#10;state, high-ranking market sources familiar with the iso&apos;s operation told&#10;dow jones newswires.&#10;but the iso fell short of ordering rolling blackouts wednesday for the third&#10;consecutive day.&#10;the iso wouldn&apos;t comment on the transactions, saying it is sensitive market&#10;information. but sources said powerex, a subsidiary of british columbia&#10;hydro &amp; power authority (x.bch), is the only energy company in the northwest&#10;region with an abundant supply of electricity to spare and the iso paid&#10;about $900 a megawatt-hour from the early afternoon through the evening.&#10;but that still wasn&apos;t enough juice.&#10;the los angeles department of water and power sold the iso 1,200 megawatts&#10;of power later in the day at the wholesale electricity price cap rate of&#10;$250/mwh. the ladwp, which is not governed by the iso, needs 3,800 megawatts&#10;of power to serve its customers. it is free sell power instate above the&#10;$250/mwh price cap.&#10;the ladwp has been very vocal about the amount of power it has to spare. the&#10;municipal utility has also reaped huge profits by selling its excess power&#10;into the grid when supply is tight and prices are high. however, the ladwp&#10;is named as a defendant in a civil lawsuit alleging price gouging. the suit&#10;claims the ladwp sells some of its power it gets from the federal bonneville&#10;power administration, which sells hydropower at cheap rates, back into the&#10;market at prices 10 times higher.&#10;powerex officials wouldn&apos;t comment on the iso power sale, saying all&#10;transactions are proprietary. but the company also sold the iso 1,000&#10;megawatts tuesday - minutes before the iso was to declare rolling blackouts&#10;- for $1,100 a megawatt-hour, market sources said.&#10;the iso, whose main job is to keep electricity flowing throughout the state&#10;no matter what the cost, started the day with a stage-two power emergency,&#10;which means its operating reserves fell to less than 5%. the iso is having&#10;to compete with investor-owned utilities in the northwest that are willing&#10;to pay higher prices for power in a region where there are no price caps.&#10;the iso warned federal regulators, generators and utilities wednesday during&#10;a conference call that it would call a stage-three power emergency&#10;wednesday, but wouldn&apos;t order rolling blackouts. a stage three is declared&#10;when the iso&apos;s operating reserves fall to less than 1.5% and power is&#10;interrupted on a statewide basis to keep the grid from collapsing.&#10;but iso spokesman patrick dorinson said it would call a stage three only as&#10;a means of attracting additional electricity resources.&#10;&quot;in order to line up (more power) we have to be in a dire situation,&quot;&#10;dorinson said.&#10;edison international unit (eix) southern california edison, sempra energy&#10;unit (sre) san diego gas &amp; electric, pg&amp;e corp. (pcg) unit pacific gas &amp;&#10;electric and several municipal utilities in the state will share the cost of&#10;the high-priced power.&#10;socal edison and pg&amp;e are facing a debt of more than $6 billion due to high&#10;wholesale electricity costs. the utilities debt this week could grow by&#10;nearly $1 billion, analysts said. it&apos;s still unclear whether retail&#10;customers will be forced to pay for the debt through higher electricity&#10;rates or if companies will absorb the costs.&#10;-by jason leopold, dow jones newswires; 323-658-3874;&#10;jason.leopold@dowjones.com&#10;(end) dow jones newswires 07-12-00&#10;1318gmt copyright (c) 2000, dow jones &amp; company inc&#10;13:17 gmt 7 december 2000 dj calif iso, puc inspect off-line duke south bay&#10;pwr plant&#10;(this article was originally published wednesday)&#10;los angeles (dow jones)--representatives of the california independent&#10;system operator and public utilities commission inspected duke energy&#10;corp.&apos;s (duk) off-line 700-mw south bay power plant in chula vista, calif.,&#10;wednesday morning, a duke spokesman said.&#10;the iso and puc have been inspecting all off-line power plants in the state&#10;since tuesday evening to verify that those plants are shut down for the&#10;reasons generators say they are, iso spokesman pat dorinson said.&#10;about 11,000 mw of power has been off the state&apos;s power grid since monday,&#10;7,000 mw of which is off-line for unplanned maintenance, according to the&#10;iso.&#10;the iso manages grid reliability.&#10;as previously reported, the iso told utilities and the federal energy&#10;regulatory commission wednesday that it would call a stage three power alert&#10;at 5 pm pst (0100 gmt thursday), meaning power reserves in the state would&#10;dip below 1.5% and rolling blackouts could be implemented to avoid grid&#10;collapse. however, the iso said the action wouldn&apos;t result in rolling&#10;blackouts.&#10;the iso and puc also inspected tuesday plants owned by dynegy inc (dyn),&#10;reliant energy inc. (rei) and southern energy inc (soe).&#10;duke&apos;s 1,500-mw moss landing plant was also inspected by puc representatives&#10;in june, when some units were off-line for repairs, the duke spokesman said.&#10;&#10;&#10; -by jessica berthold, dow jones newswires; 323-658-3872;&#10;jessica.berthold@dowjones.com&#10;&#10;(end) dow jones newswires 07-12-00&#10;1317gmt copyright (c) 2000, dow jones &amp; company inc&#10;13:17 gmt 7 december 2000 =dj calif regulators visit aes,dynegy off-line&#10;power plants&#10;(this article was originally published wednesday)&#10;&#10; by jessica berthold&#10; of dow jones newswires&#10;&#10;los angeles (dow jones)--aes corp. (aes) and dynegy inc. (dyn) said&#10;wednesday that representatives of california power officials had stopped by&#10;some of their power plants to verify that they were off line for legitimate&#10;reasons.&#10;the california independent system operator, which manages the state&apos;s power&#10;grid and one of its wholesale power markets, and the california public&#10;utilities commission began on-site inspections tuesday night of all power&#10;plants in the state reporting that unplanned outages have forced shutdowns,&#10;iso spokesman pat dorinson said.&#10;the state has had 11,000 mw off the grid since monday, 7,000 mw for&#10;unplanned maintenance. the iso wednesday called a stage 2 power emergency&#10;for the third consecutive day, meaning power reserves were below 5% and&#10;customers who agreed to cut power in exchange for reduced rates may be&#10;called on to do so.&#10;as reported earlier, reliant energy (rei) and southern energy inc. (soe)&#10;said they had been visited by representatives of the iso and puc tuesday&#10;evening.&#10;representatives of the two organizations also visited plants owned by aes&#10;and dynegy tuesday evening.&#10;aes told the visitors they couldn&apos;t perform an unannounced full inspection&#10;of the company&apos;s 450-megawatt huntington beach power station until wednesday&#10;morning, when the plant&apos;s full staff would be present, aes spokesman aaron&#10;thomas said.&#10;thomas, as well as an iso spokesman, didn&apos;t know whether the representatives&#10;returned wednesday for a full inspection.&#10;&#10; aes units down due to expired emissions credits&#10;&#10;the huntington beach facility and units at two other aes facilities have&#10;used up their nitrogen oxide, or nox, emission credits. they were taken down&#10;two weeks ago in response to a request by the south coast air quality&#10;management district to stay off line until emissions controls are deployed,&#10;thomas said.&#10;aes has about 2,000 mw, or half its maximum output, off line. the entire&#10;huntington plant is off line, as is 1,500 mw worth of units at its alamitos&#10;and redondo beach plants.&#10;the iso has asked aes to return its off line plants to operations, but aes&#10;has refused because it is concerned the air quality district will fine the&#10;company $20 million for polluting.&#10;&quot;we&apos;d be happy to put our units back, provided we don&apos;t get sued for it,&quot;&#10;thomas said. &quot;it&apos;s not clear to us that the iso trumps the air quality&#10;district&apos;s&quot; authority.&#10;as reported, a spokesman for the air quality district said tuesday that aes&#10;could have elected to buy more emission credits so that it could run its off&#10;line plants in case of power emergencies, but choose not to do so.&#10;&#10; dynegy&apos;s el segundo plant also visited by puc&#10;&#10;dynegy inc. (dyn) said the puc visited its 1,200 mw el segundo plant tuesday&#10;evening, where two of the four units, about 600 mw worth, were off line&#10;wednesday.&#10;&quot;i guess our position is, &apos;gee, we&apos;re sorry you don&apos;t believe us, but if you&#10;need to come and take a look for yourself, that&apos;s fine,&apos;&quot; said dynegy&#10;spokesman lynn lednicky.&#10;lednicky said one of the two units was off line for planned maintenance and&#10;the other for unplanned maintenance on boiler feedwater pumps, which could&#10;pose a safety hazard if not repaired.&#10;&quot;we&apos;ve been doing all we can to get back in service,&quot; lednicky said. &quot;we&#10;even paid to have some specialized equipment expedited.&quot;&#10;lednicky added that the puc seemed satisfied with dynegy&apos;s explanation of&#10;why its units were off line.&#10;-by jessica berthold, dow jones newswires; 323-658-3872,&#10;jessica.berthold@dowjones.com&#10;(end) dow jones newswires 07-12-00&#10;1317gmt copyright (c) 2000, dow jones &amp; company inc&#10;&#10;&#10;g_nther a. pergher&#10;senior analyst&#10;dow jones &amp; company inc.&#10;tel. 609.520.7067&#10;fax. 609.452.3531&#10;&#10;the information transmitted is intended only for the person or entity to&#10;which it is addressed and may contain confidential and/or privileged&#10;material. any review, retransmission, dissemination or other use of, or&#10;taking of any action in reliance upon, this information by persons or&#10;entities other than the intended recipient is prohibited. if you received&#10;this in error, please contact the sender and delete the material from any&#10;computer.&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

417:<mail><row>417</row><date>2001/03/08</date><from>phillip.allen@enron.com</from><to>gthorse@keyad.com</to><subj>sagewood phase ii</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>---------------------- forwarded by phillip k allen/hou/ect on 03/08/2001 &#10;01:32 pm ---------------------------&#10;&#10;&#10;andrew_m_ozuna@bankone.com on 03/07/2001 11:41:43 am&#10;to: phillip.k.allen@enron.com&#10;cc: &#10;subject: sagewood phase ii&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;---------------------- forwarded by andrew m ozuna/tx/bancone on 03/07/2001&#10;01:41 pm ---------------------------&#10;&#10;&#10;andrew m ozuna&#10;03/06/2001 03:14 pm&#10;&#10;to: &quot;george richards&quot; &lt;cbpres@austin.rr.com&gt;&#10;cc:&#10;subject: sagewood phase ii&#10;&#10;&#10;george,&#10;&#10;thank you for the opportunity to review your financing request for the &#10;sagewood&#10;phase ii project. upon receipt of all the requested information regarding the&#10;project, we completed somewhat of a due diligence on the market. there are a&#10;number of concerns which need to be addressed prior to the bank moving forward&#10;on the transaction. first, the pro-forma rental rates, when compared on a&#10;bedroom to bedroom basis, are high relative to the market. we adjusted&#10;pro-forma downward to match the market rates and the rates per bedroom we are&#10;acheiving on the existing sagewood project. additionally, there are about &#10;500+&#10;units coming on-line within the next 12 months in the city of san marcos, &#10;this,&#10;we believe will causes some downward rent pressures which can have a serious&#10;effect on an over leveraged project. we have therefore adjusted the requested&#10;loan amount to $8,868,000.&#10;&#10;i have summarized our issues as follows:&#10;&#10;1. pro-forma rental rates were adjusted downward to market as follows:&#10;&#10; pro-forma bank&apos;s adjustment&#10; unit unit rent rent/br unit rent rent/br&#10; 2 br/2.5 ba $1,150 $575 $950 $475&#10; 3 br/unit $1,530 $510 $1,250 $417&#10;&#10;2. pro-forma expenses were increased to include a $350/unit reserve for unit&#10;turn over.&#10;&#10;3. a market vacancy factor of 5% was applied to potential gross income (pgi).&#10;&#10;4. based on the bank&apos;s revised n.o.i. of $1,075,000, the project can support&#10;debt in the amount of $8,868,000, and maintain our loan parameters of 1.25x &#10;debt&#10;coverage ratio, on a 25 year amo., and 8.60% phantom interest rate.&#10;&#10;5. the debt service will be approx. $874,000/year.&#10;&#10;6. given the debt of $8,868,000, the borrower will be required to provide&#10;equity of $2,956,000, consisting of the following:&#10;&#10; land - $1,121,670&#10; deferred profit&amp; overhead $ 415,000&#10; cash equity $1,419,268&#10; total $2,955,938&#10;&#10;7. equity credit for deferred profit and overhead was limited to a percentage &#10;of&#10;actual hard construction costs.&#10;&#10;(see attached file: mapttra.xls)&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10; 490:<mail><row>490</row><date>2001/02/06</date><from>phillip.allen@enron.com</from><to>jsmith@austintx.com</to><subj></subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>jeff,&#10;&#10;i am not willing to guarantee to refinance the 1st lien on the stage in 4 &#10;years and drop the rate on both notes at that point to 8%. there are several &#10;reasons that i won&apos;t commit to this. exposure to interest fluctuations, the &#10;large cash reserves needed, and the limited financial resources of the buyer &#10;are the three biggest concerns. &#10;&#10;what i am willing to do is lower the second note to 8% amortized over the &#10;buyers choice of terms up to 30 years. the existing note does not come due &#10;until september 2009. that is a long time. the buyer may have sold the &#10;property. interest rates may be lower. i am bending over backwards to make &#10;the deal work with such an attractive second note. guaranteeing to refinance &#10;is pushing too far.&#10;&#10;can you clarify the dates in the contract. is the effective date the day the &#10;earnest money is receipted or is it once the feasibility study is complete?&#10;&#10;hopefully the buyer can live with these terms. i got your fax from the new &#10;braunfels buyer. if we can&apos;t come to terms with the first buyer i will get &#10;started on the list.&#10;&#10;email or call me later today.&#10;&#10;phillip&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

cpuc audit report on edison&#10;&#10;the following are the highlights from the executive summary of the kpmg aud=&#10;it=20&#10;report on southern california edison:&#10;=20&#10;i. cash needs&#10;highlights:&#10;sce=01,s original cash forecast, dated as december 28, 2000, projects a com=&#10;plete=20&#10;cash depletion date of february 1, 2001. since then sce has instituted a=20&#10;program of cash conservation that includes suspension of certain obligation=&#10;s=20&#10;and other measures.=20&#10;based on daily cash forecasts and cash conservation activities, sce=01,s=20&#10;available cash improved through january 19 from an original estimate of $51=&#10;.8=20&#10;million to $1.226 billion. the actual cash flow, given these cash=20&#10;conservation activities, extends the cash depletion date.&#10;ii. credit relationships&#10;highlights:&#10;sce has exercised all available lines of credit and has not been able to=20&#10;extend or renew credit as it has become due.&#10;at present, there are no additional sources of credit open to sce.&#10;sce=01,s loan agreements provide for specific clauses with respect to defau=&#10;lt.=20&#10;generally, these agreements provide for the debt becoming immediately due a=&#10;nd=20&#10;payable.&#10;sce=01,s utility plant assets are used to secure outstanding mortgage bond=&#10;=20&#10;indebtedness, although there is some statutory capacity to issue more=20&#10;indebtedness if it were feasible to do so.&#10;credit ratings agencies have downgraded sce=01,s credit ratings on most of =&#10;its=20&#10;rated indebtedness from solid corporate ratings to below investment grade=&#10;=20&#10;issues within the last three weeks.&#10;iii. energy cost scenarios&#10;highlights&#10;this report section uses different cpuc supplied assumptions to assess=20&#10;various price scenarios upon sce=01,s projected cash depletion dates. under=&#10; such=20&#10;scenarios, sce would have a positive cash balance until march 30, 2001.&#10;iv. cost containment initiatives&#10;highlights&#10;sce has adopted a $460 million cost reduction plan for the year 2001.&#10;the plan consists of an operation and maintenance component and a capital=&#10;=20&#10;improvement component as follows (in millions):&#10;operating and maintenance costs $ 77&#10;capital improvement costs 383&#10;total $ 460&#10;the plan provides for up to 2,000 full, part-time and contract positions to=&#10;=20&#10;be eliminated with approximately 75% of the total staff reduction coming fr=&#10;om=20&#10;contract employees.&#10;under the plan, capital improvement costs totaling $383 million are for the=&#10;=20&#10;most part being deferred to a future date.&#10;sce dividends to its common shareholder and preferred stockholders and=20&#10;executive bonuses have been suspended, resulting in an additional cost=20&#10;savings of approximately $92 million.&#10;v. accounting mechanisms to track stranded cost recovery (tra and tcba=20&#10;activity)&#10;highlights:&#10;as of december 31, 2000, sce reported an overcollected balance in the=20&#10;transition cost balancing account (tcba) account of $494.5 million. this=20&#10;includes an estimated market valuation of its hydro facilities of $500=20&#10;million and accelerated revenues of $175 million.&#10;as of december 31, 2000, sce reported an undercollected balance in sce=01,s=&#10;=20&#10;transition account (tra) of $4.49 billion.&#10;normally, the generation memorandum accounts are credited to the tcba at th=&#10;e=20&#10;end of each year. however, the current generation memorandum account credit=&#10;=20&#10;balance of $1.5 billion has not been credited to the tcba, pursuant to=20&#10;d.01-01-018.&#10;costs of purchasing generation are tracked in the tra and revenues from=20&#10;generation are tracked in the tcba. because these costs and revenues are=20&#10;tracked separately, the net liability from procuring electric power, as=20&#10;expressed in the tra, are overstated.&#10;turn proposal&#10;as part of our review, the cpuc asked that we comment on the proposal of tu=&#10;rn=20&#10;to change certain aspects of the regulatory accounting for transition asset=&#10;s.=20&#10;our comments are summarized as follows:&#10;the proposal would have no direct impact on the cash flows of sce in that i=&#10;t=20&#10;would not directly generate nor use cash.&#10;the proposal=01,s impact on sce=01,s balance sheet would initially be to sh=&#10;ift=20&#10;costs between two regulatory assets.&#10;turn=01,s proposal recognizes that because the costs of procuring power and=&#10; the=20&#10;revenues from generating power are tracked separately, the undercollection =&#10;in=20&#10;the tra is overstated.&#10;vi. flow of funds analysis&#10;highlights:&#10;in the last five years, sce had generated net income of $2.7 billion and a=&#10;=20&#10;positive cash flow from operations of $7 billion.&#10;during the same time period, sce paid dividends and other distributions to=&#10;=20&#10;its parent, edison international, of approximately $4.8 billion.&#10;edison international used the funds from dividends to pay dividends to its=&#10;=20&#10;shareholders of $1.6 billion and repurchased shares of its outstanding comm=&#10;on=20&#10;stock of $2.7 billion, with the remaining funds being used for administrati=&#10;ve=20&#10;and general costs, investments, and other corporate purposes.&#10;[there is no section vii]&#10;=20&#10;viii. earnings of california affiliates&#10;sce=01,s payments for power to its affiliates were approximately $400-$500=&#10;=20&#10;million annually and remained relatively stable from 1996 through 1999.=20&#10;in 2000, the payments increased by approximately 50% to over $600 million.=&#10;=20&#10;this increase correlates to the increase in market prices&#10;for natural gas for the same period.&#10;a copy of the report is available on the commission website at=20&#10;www.cpuc.ca.gov.&#10;=20&#10;dan&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

527:<mail><row>527</row><date>2001/01/22</date><from>phillip.allen@enron.com</from><to>mike.grigsby@enron.com</to><subj></subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>by steve everly - the kansas city star&#10;date: 01/20/01 22:15&#10;&#10;as natural gas prices rose in december, traders at the new york mercantile &#10;exchange kept one eye on the weather forecast and another on a weekly gas &#10;storage number. &#10;&#10;the storage figures showed utilities withdrawing huge amounts of gas, and the &#10;forecast was for frigid weather. traders put the two together, anticipated a &#10;supply crunch and drove gas prices to record heights. &#10;&#10;&quot;traders do that all the time; they&apos;re looking forward,&quot; said william burson, &#10;a trader. &quot;it makes the market for natural gas.&quot; &#10;&#10;but the market&apos;s response perplexed chris mcgill, the american gas &#10;association&apos;s director of gas supply and transportation. he had compiled the &#10;storage numbers since they were first published in 1994, and in his view the &#10;numbers were being misinterpreted to show a situation far bleaker than &#10;reality. &#10;&#10;&quot;it&apos;s a little frustrating that they don&apos;t take the time to understand what &#10;we are reporting,&quot; mcgill said. &#10;&#10;as consumer outrage builds over high heating bills, the hunt for reasons -- &#10;and culprits -- is on. some within the natural gas industry are pointing &#10;fingers at wall street. &#10;&#10;stephen adik, senior vice president of the indiana utility nisource, recently &#10;stepped before an industry conference and blamed the market&apos;s speculators for &#10;the rise in gas prices. &#10;&#10;&quot;it&apos;s my firm belief ... that today&apos;s gas prices are being manipulated,&quot; adik &#10;told the trade magazine public utilities fortnightly. &#10;&#10;in california, where natural gas spikes have contributed to an electric &#10;utility crisis, six investigations are looking into the power industry. &#10;&#10;closer to home, observers note that utilities and regulators share the blame &#10;for this winter&apos;s startling gas bills, having failed to protect their &#10;customers and constituents from such price spikes. &#10;&#10;most utilities, often with the acquiescence of regulators, failed to take &#10;precautions such as fixed-rate contracts and hedging -- a sort of price &#10;insurance -- that could have protected their customers by locking in gas &#10;prices before they soared. &#10;&#10;&quot;we&apos;re passing on our gas costs, which we have no control over,&quot; said paul &#10;snider, a spokesman for missouri gas energy. &#10;&#10;but critics say the utilities shirked their responsibility to customers. &#10;&#10;&quot;there&apos;s been a failure of risk management by utilities, and that needs to &#10;change,&quot; said ed krapels, director of gas power services for energy security &#10;analysis inc., an energy consulting firm in wakefield, mass. &#10;&#10;&#10;hot topic &#10;&#10;consumers know one thing for certain: their heating bills are up sharply. in &#10;many circles, little else is discussed. &#10;&#10;the rev. vincent fraser of glad tidings assembly of god in kansas city is &#10;facing a $1,456 december bill for heating the church -- more than double the &#10;previous december&apos;s bill. church members are suffering from higher bills as &#10;well. &#10;&#10;the sunday collection is down, said fraser, who might have to forgo part of &#10;his salary. for the first time, the church is unable to meet its financial &#10;pledge to overseas missionaries because the money is going to heating. &#10;&#10;&quot;it&apos;s the talk of the town here,&quot; he said. &#10;&#10;a year ago that wasn&apos;t a fear. wholesale gas prices hovered just above $2 per &#10;thousand cubic feet -- a level that producers say didn&apos;t make it worthwhile &#10;to drill for gas. utilities were even cutting the gas prices paid by &#10;customers. &#10;&#10;but trouble was brewing. by spring, gas prices were hitting $4 per thousand &#10;cubic feet, just as utilities were beginning to buy gas to put into storage &#10;for winter. &#10;&#10;there was a dip in the fall, but then prices rebounded. by early november, &#10;prices were at $5 per thousand cubic feet. the federal energy information &#10;administration was predicting sufficient but tight gas supplies and heating &#10;bills that would be 30 percent to 40 percent higher. &#10;&#10;but $10 gas was coming. below-normal temperatures hit much of the country, &#10;including the kansas city area, and fears about tight supplies roiled the gas &#10;markets. &#10;&#10;&quot;it&apos;s all about the weather,&quot; said krapels of energy security analysis. &#10;&#10;wholesale prices exploded to $10 per thousand cubic feet, led by the new york &#10;traders. natural gas sealed its reputation as the most price-volatile &#10;commodity in the world. &#10;&#10;&#10;setting the price &#10;&#10;in the 1980s, the federal government took the caps off the wellhead price of &#10;gas, allowing it to float. in 1990, the new york mercantile began trading &#10;contracts for future delivery of natural gas, and that market soon had &#10;widespread influence over gas prices. &#10;&#10;the futures contracts are bought and sold for delivery of natural gas as soon &#10;as next month or as far ahead as three years. suppliers can lock in sale &#10;prices for the gas they expect to produce. and big gas consumers, from &#10;utilities to companies such as farmland industries inc., can lock in what &#10;they pay for the gas they expect to use. &#10;&#10;there are also speculators who trade the futures contracts with no intention &#10;of actually buying or selling the gas -- and often with little real knowledge &#10;of natural gas. &#10;&#10;but if they get on the right side of a price trend, traders don&apos;t need to &#10;know much about gas -- or whatever commodity they&apos;re trading. like all &#10;futures, the gas contracts are purchased on credit. that leverage adds to &#10;their volatility and to the traders&apos; ability to make or lose a lot of money &#10;in a short time. &#10;&#10;as december began, the price of natural gas on the futures market was less &#10;than $7 per thousand cubic feet. by the end of the month it was nearly $10. &#10;much of the spark for the rally came from the american gas association&apos;s &#10;weekly storage numbers. &#10;&#10;utilities buy ahead and store as much as 50 percent of the gas they expect to &#10;need in the winter. &#10;&#10;going into the winter, the storage levels were about 5 percent less than &#10;average, in part because some utilities were holding off on purchasing, in &#10;hopes that the summer&apos;s unusually high $4 to $5 prices would drop. &#10;&#10;still, the american gas association offered assurances that supplies would be &#10;sufficient. but when below-normal temperatures arrived in november, the &#10;concerns increased among traders that supplies could be insufficient. &#10;&#10;then the american gas association reported the lowest year-end storage &#10;numbers since they were first published in 1994. still, said the &#10;association&apos;s mcgill, there was sufficient gas in storage. &#10;&#10;but some utility executives didn&apos;t share that view. william eliason, vice &#10;president of kansas gas service, said that if december&apos;s cold snap had &#10;continued into january, there could have been a real problem meeting demand. &#10;&#10;&quot;i was getting worried,&quot; he said. &#10;&#10;then suddenly the market turned when january&apos;s weather turned warmer. &#10;wednesday&apos;s storage numbers were better than expected, and futures prices &#10;dropped more than $1 per thousand cubic feet. &#10;&#10;&#10;just passing through &#10;&#10;some utilities said there was little else to do about the price increase but &#10;pass their fuel costs on to customers. &#10;&#10;among area utilities, kansas gas service increased its customers&apos; cost-of-gas &#10;charge earlier this month to $8.68 per thousand cubic feet. and missouri gas &#10;energy has requested an increase to $9.81, to begin wednesday. &#10;&#10;sheila lumpe, chairwoman of the missouri public service commission, said last &#10;month that because utilities passed along their wholesale costs, little could &#10;be done besides urging consumers to join a level-payment plan and to conserve &#10;energy. &#10;&#10;kansas gas service had a small hedging program in place, which is expected to &#10;save an average customer about $25 this winter. &#10;&#10;missouri gas energy has no hedging program. it waited until fall to seek an &#10;extension of the program and then decided to pass when regulators would not &#10;guarantee that it could recover its hedging costs. &#10;&#10;now utilities are being asked to justify the decisions that have left &#10;customers with such high gas bills. and regulators are being asked whether &#10;they should abandon the practice of letting utilities pass along their fuel &#10;costs. &#10;&#10;on friday, doug micheel, senior counsel of the missouri office of the public &#10;counsel, said his office would ask the missouri public service commission to &#10;perform an emergency audit of missouri gas energy&apos;s gas purchasing practices. &#10;&#10;&quot;consumers are taking all the risk,&quot; micheel said. &quot;it&apos;s time to consider &#10;some changes.&quot; &#10;&#10;&#10;to reach steve everly, call (816) 234-4455 or send e-mail to &#10;severly@kcstar.com. &#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;------------------------------------------------------------------------------&#10;--&#10;all content , 2001 the kansas city star </body></mail>

556:<mail><row>556</row><date>2000/12/29</date><from>phillip.allen@enron.com</from><to>mike.grigsby@enron.com,jane.tholt@enron.com,frank.ermis@enron.com,tori.kuykendall@enron.com</to><subj>meeting with governor davis, need for additional comments/suggestions</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>---------------------- forwarded by phillip k allen/hou/ect on 12/29/2000 &#10;10:13 am ---------------------------&#10;from: steven j kean@enron on 12/28/2000 09:19 pm cst&#10;to: tim belden/hou/ect@ect, phillip k allen/hou/ect@ect, david &#10;parquet/sf/ect@ect, marty sunde/hou/ees@ees, william s bradford/hou/ect@ect, &#10;scott stoness/hou/ees@ees, dennis benevides/hou/ees@ees, robert &#10;badeer/hou/ect@ect, jeff dasovich/na/enron@enron, sandra &#10;mccubbin/na/enron@enron, susan j mara/na/enron@enron, richard &#10;shapiro/na/enron@enron, james d steffes/na/enron@enron, paul &#10;kaufman/pdx/ect@ect, mary hain/hou/ect@ect, joe hartsoe/corp/enron@enron, &#10;mark palmer/corp/enron@enron, karen denne/corp/enron@enron&#10;cc: &#10;subject: meeting with governor davis, need for additional comments/suggestions&#10;&#10;we met with gov davis on thursday evening in la. in attendance were ken lay, &#10;the governor, the governor&apos;s staff director (kari dohn) and myself. the gov. &#10;spent over an hour and a half with us covering our suggestions and his &#10;ideas. he would like some additional thoughts from us by tuesday of next &#10;week as he prepares his state of the state address for the following monday. &#10;attached to the end of this memo is a list of solutions we proposed (based on &#10;my discussions with several of you) as well as some background materials jeff &#10;dasovich and i prepared. below are my notes from the meeting regarding our &#10;proposals, the governor&apos;s ideas, as well as my overview of the situation &#10;based on the governor&apos;s comments:&#10;&#10;overview: we made great progress in both ensuring that he understands that &#10;we are different from the generators and in opening a channel for ongoing &#10;communication with his administration. the gov does not want the utilities to &#10;go bankrupt and seems predisposed to both rate relief (more modest than what &#10;the utilities are looking for) and credit guarantees. his staff has more &#10;work to do on the latter, but he was clearly intrigued with the idea. he &#10;talked mainly in terms of raising rates but not uncapping them at the retail &#10;level. he also wants to use what generation he has control over for the &#10;benefit of california consumers, including utility-owned generation (which he &#10;would dedicate to consumers on a cost-plus basis) and excess muni power &#10;(which he estimates at 3000mw). he foresees a mix of market oriented &#10;solutions as well as interventionist solutions which will allow him to fix &#10;the problem by &apos;02 and provide some political cover.&#10;our proposals: i have attached the outline we put in front of him (it also &#10;included the forward price information several of you provided). he seemed &#10;interested in 1) the buy down of significant demand, 2) the state setting a &#10;goal of x000 mw of new generation by a date certain, 3) getting the utilities &#10;to gradually buy more power forward and 4) setting up a group of rate &#10;analysts and other &quot;nonadvocates&quot; to develop solutions to a number of issues &#10;including designing the portfolio and forward purchase terms for utilities. &#10;he was also quite interested in examining the incentives surrounding ldc gas &#10;purchases. as already mentioned, he was also favorably disposed to finding &#10;some state sponsored credit support for the utilities.&#10;his ideas: the gov read from a list of ideas some of which were obviously &#10;under serious consideration and some of which were mere &quot;brainstorming&quot;. &#10;some of these ideas would require legislative action.&#10;state may build (or make build/transfer arrangements) a &quot;couple&quot; of &#10;generation plants. the gov feels strongly that he has to show consumers that &#10;they are getting something in return for bearing some rate increases. this &#10;was a frequently recurring theme.&#10;utilities would sell the output from generation they still own on a cost-plus &#10;basis to consumers.&#10;municipal utilties would be required to sell their excess generation in &#10;california.&#10;state universities (including uc/csu and the community colleges) would more &#10;widely deploy distributed generation.&#10;expand in-state gas production.&#10;take state lands gas royalties in kind.&#10;negotiate directly with tribes and state governments in the west for &#10;addtional gas supplies.&#10;empower an existing state agency to approve/coordinate power plant &#10;maintenance schedules to avoid having too much generation out of service at &#10;any one time.&#10;condition emissions offsets on commitments to sell power longer term in state.&#10;either eliminate the iso or sharply curtail its function -- he wants to hear &#10;more about how nordpool works(jeff- someone in schroeder&apos;s group should be &#10;able to help out here).&#10;wants to condition new generation on a commitment to sell in state. we made &#10;some headway with the idea that he could instead require utilities to buy &#10;some portion of their forward requirements from new in-state generation &#10;thereby accomplishing the same thing without using a command and control &#10;approach with generators.&#10;securitize uncollected power purchase costs.&#10;to dos: (jeff, again i&apos;d like to prevail on you to assemble the group&apos;s &#10;thoughts and get them to kari)&#10;he wants to see 5 year fixed power prices for peak/ off-peak and baseload -- &#10;not just the 5 one year strips.&#10;he wants comments on his proposals by tuesday.&#10;he would like thoughts on how to pitch what consumers are getting out of the &#10;deal.&#10;he wants to assemble a group of energy gurus to help sort through some of the &#10;forward contracting issues.&#10;thanks to everyone for their help. we made some progress today.&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

563:<mail><row>563</row><date>2000/12/22</date><from>phillip.allen@enron.com</from><to>steven.kean@enron.com</to><subj></subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>steve,&#10;&#10;&#10;i am sending you a variety of charts with prices and operational detail. if &#10;you need to call with questions my home number is 713-463-8626.&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;as far as recommendations, here is a short list:&#10;&#10; 1. examine ldc&apos;s incentive rate program. current methodology rewards sales &#10;above monthly index without enough consideration of future &#10; replacement cost. the result is that the ldc&apos;s sell gas that should be &#10;injected into storage when daily prices run above the monthly index.&#10; this creates a shortage in later months.&#10;&#10; 2. california has the storage capacity and pipeline capacity to meet &#10;demand. investigate why it wasn&apos;t maximized operationally. &#10; specific questions should include: &#10;&#10; 1. why in march &apos;00-may &apos;00 weren&apos;t total system receipts higher in order &#10;to fill storage?&#10;&#10; 2. why are there so many examples of ofo&apos;s on weekends that push away too &#10;much gas from socal&apos;s system. &#10; i believe socal gas does an extremely poor job of forecasting their &#10;own demand. they repeatedly estimated they would receive more gas than &#10;their injection capablity, but injected far less.&#10;&#10; 3. similar to the power market, there is too much benchmarking to short &#10;term prices. not enough forward hedging is done by the major &#10; ldcs. by design the customers are short at a floating &#10;rate. this market has been long historically. it has been a buyers market &#10;and the &#10; consumer has benefitted. &#10;&#10;&#10;call me if you need any more input.&#10;&#10;&#10;phillip</body></mail>

617:<mail><row>617</row><date>2000/10/24</date><from>phillip.allen@enron.com</from><to>keith.holst@enron.com</to><subj>investment structure</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>---------------------- forwarded by phillip k allen/hou/ect on 10/24/2000 &#10;01:29 pm ---------------------------&#10;&#10;&#10;&quot;george richards&quot; &lt;cbpres@austin.rr.com&gt; on 09/26/2000 01:18:45 pm&#10;please respond to &lt;cbpres@austin.rr.com&gt;&#10;to: &quot;phillip allen&quot; &lt;pallen@enron.com&gt;&#10;cc: &quot;larry lewter&quot; &lt;retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net&gt;, &quot;claudia l. crocker&quot; &#10;&lt;clclegal2@aol.com&gt; &#10;subject: investment structure&#10;&#10;&#10;structure:&#10;typically the structure is a limited partnership with a corporate (or llc)&#10;general partner. the general partner owns 1% of the project and carries the&#10;liability of construction.&#10;&#10;land ownership &amp; loans&#10;the property would be purchased in the name of the limited partnership and&#10;any land loans, land improvements loans and construction loans would be in&#10;the name of the limited partnership. each of the individual investors and&#10;all of the principals in creekside would also personally guarantee the&#10;loans. if the investor(s) do not sign on the loans, this generally means&#10;that a larger amount of cash is required and the investor&apos;s share of profits&#10;is reduced.&#10;&#10;all loans for residential construction, that are intended for re-sale, are&#10;full recourse loans. if we are pursuing multifamily rental developments,&#10;the construction loans are still full recourse but the mortgage can often be&#10;non-recourse.&#10;&#10;use of initial investment&#10;the initial investment is used for land deposit, engineering &amp;&#10;architectural design, soils tests, surveys, filing fees, legal fees for&#10;organization and condominium association formation, and appraisals. unlike&#10;many real estate investment programs, none of the funds are used for fees to&#10;creekside builders, llc. these professional expenses will be incurred over&#10;the estimated 6 month design and approval period.&#10;&#10;early land costs&#10;the $4,000 per month costs listed in the cash flow as part of land cost&#10;represent the extension fees due to the seller for up to 4 months of&#10;extensions on closing. as an alternative, we can close into a land loan at&#10;probably 70% of appraised value. with a land value equal to the purchase&#10;price of $680,000 this would mean a land loan of $476,000 with estimated&#10;monthly interest payments of $3,966, given a 10% annual interest rate, plus&#10;approximately 1.25% of the loan amount for closing costs and loan fees.&#10;&#10;equity at improvement loan&#10;once the site plan is approved by the city of austin, the city will require&#10;the development entity to post funds for fiscal improvements, referred to as&#10;the &quot;fiscals&quot;. this cost represents a bond for the completion of&#10;improvements that coa considers vital and these funds are released once the&#10;improvements have been completed and accepted by coa. this release will be&#10;for 90% of the cost with the remaining 10% released one year after&#10;completion. releases can be granted once every 90 days and you should&#10;expect that the release would occur 6 months after the start of lot&#10;improvement construction. these fiscals are usually posted in cash or an&#10;irrevocable letter of credit. as such, they have to be counted as a&#10;development cost, even though they are not spent. because they are not&#10;spent no interest is charged on these funds.&#10;&#10;the lot improvement loan is typically 75% of the appraised value of a&#10;finished lot, which i suspect will be at least $20,000 and potentially as&#10;high as $25,000. this would produce a loan amount of $15,000 on $20,000&#10;per lot. with estimated per lot improvement costs of $9,000, &apos;fiscals&apos; at&#10;$2,000 and the land cost at $8,000 , total improved lot cost is $19,000&#10;which means $0 to $4,000 per lot in total equity. the investment prior to&#10;obtaining the improvement loan would count towards any equity requirement&#10;provided it was for direct costs. thus, the additional equity for the&#10;improvement loan would be $0-$184,000. even if the maximum loan would&#10;cover all costs, it is unlikely the bank would allow reimbursement of funds&#10;spent. the higher estimates of equity investments are shown in the&#10;preliminary proforma to be on the safe side. the engineer is preparing a&#10;tentative site layout with an initial evaluation of the phasing, which can&#10;significantly reduce the cash equity requirement.&#10;&#10;phasing works as follows. if the first phase was say 40 units, the total&#10;lot improvement cost might average $31,000 per lot. of this, probably&#10;$13,000 would be for improvements and $19,000 for the land cost. the&#10;improvements are higher to cover large one time up front costs for design&#10;costs, the entry road, water treatment costs, perimeter fencing and&#10;landscaping, and so on, as well as for 100% of the land. the land loan for&#10;undeveloped lots would be 70% of the appraised raw lot value, which i would&#10;estimate as $10,000 per lot for a loan value of $7,000 per lot. then the&#10;loan value for each improved lot would be $15,000 per lot. this would give&#10;you a total loan of $992,000, total cost of $1,232,645 for equity required&#10;of $241,000. this was not presented in the initial analysis as the phasing&#10;is depended on a more careful assessment by the civil engineer as the&#10;separate phases must each be able to stand on its own from a utility&#10;standpoint.&#10;&#10;construction loans&#10;there are three types of construction loans. first, is a speculative&#10;(spec) loan that is taken out prior to any pre-sales activity. second, is&#10;a construction loan for a pre-sold unit, but the loan remains in the&#10;builder/developers name. third, is a pre-sold unit with the construction&#10;loan in the name of the buyer. we expect to have up to 8 spec loans to&#10;start the project and expect all other loans to be pre-sold units with loans&#10;in the name of the builder/developer. we do not expect to have any&#10;construction loans in the name of the buyers, as such loans are too&#10;difficult to manage and please new buyers unfamiliar with the process.&#10;&#10;spec loans will be for 70% to 75% of value and construction loans for&#10;pre-sold units, if the construction loan is from the mortgage lender, will&#10;be from 80% to 95% of value.&#10;&#10;disbursements&#10;disbursements will be handled by the general partner to cover current and&#10;near term third party costs, then to necessary reserves, then to priority&#10;payments and then to the partners per the agreement. the general partner&#10;will contract with creekside builders, llc to construct the units and the&#10;fee to cb will include a construction management and overhead fee equal to&#10;15% of the direct hard cost excluding land, financing and sales costs.&#10;these fees are the only monies to creekside, larry lewter or myself prior to&#10;calculation of profit, except for a) direct reimbursement for partnership&#10;expenses and b) direct payment to cb for any subcontractor costs that it has&#10;to perform. for example, if cb cannot find a good trim carpenter sub, or&#10;cannot find enough trim carpenters, etc., and it decides to undertake this&#10;function, it will charge the partnership the same fee it was able to obtain&#10;from third parties and will disclose those cases to the partnership.&#10;finally, cb will receive a fee for the use of any of its equipment if it is&#10;used in lieu of leasing equipment from others. at present cb does not own&#10;any significant equipment, but it is considering the purchase of a sky track&#10;to facilitate and speed up framing, cornice, roofing and drywall spreading.&#10;&#10;reporting&#10;we are more than willing to provide reports to track expenses vs. plan.&#10;what did you have in mind? i would like to use some form of internet based&#10;reporting.&#10;&#10;bookkeeping&#10;i am not sure what you are referring to by the question, &quot;bookkeeping&#10;procedures to record actual expenses?&quot; please expand.&#10;&#10;investor input&#10;we are glad to have the investor&apos;s input on design and materials. as always&#10;the question will be who has final say if there is disagreement, but in my&#10;experience i have always been able to reach consensus. as you, and i presume&#10;keith, want to be involved to learn as much as possible we would make every&#10;effort to be accommodating.&#10;&#10;creekside proceedures&#10;cb procedures for dealing with subs, vendors and professionals is not as&#10;formal as your question indicates. in the extremely tight labor market&#10;obtaining 3 bids for each labor trade is not feasible. for the professional&#10;subs we use those with whom we have developed a previous rapport. finally,&#10;for vendors they are constantly shopped.&#10;&#10;pre-selected professionals, subs and vendors&#10;yes there are many different subs that have been identified and i can&#10;provide these if you are interested.&#10;&#10;i know i have not answered everything, but this is a starting point. call&#10;when you have reviewed and we can discuss further.&#10;&#10;sincerely,&#10;&#10;george richards&#10;president, creekside builders, llc&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10; - winmail.dat&#10;</body></mail>

626:<mail><row>626</row><date>2000/10/16</date><from>phillip.allen@enron.com</from><to>zimam@enron.com</to><subj>fw: fixed forward or other collar floor gas price terms</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>---------------------- forwarded by phillip k allen/hou/ect on 10/16/2000 &#10;01:42 pm ---------------------------&#10;&#10;&#10;&quot;buckner, buck&quot; &lt;buck.buckner@honeywell.com&gt; on 10/12/2000 01:12:21 pm&#10;to: &quot;&apos;pallen@enron.com&apos;&quot; &lt;pallen@enron.com&gt;&#10;cc: &#10;subject: fw: fixed forward or other collar floor gas price terms&#10;&#10;&#10;phillip,&#10;&#10;&gt; as discussed during our phone conversation, in a parallon 75 microturbine&#10;&gt; power generation deal for a national accounts customer, i am developing a&#10;&gt; proposal to sell power to customer at fixed or collar/floor price. to do&#10;&gt; so i need a corresponding term gas price for same. microturbine is an&#10;&gt; onsite generation product developed by honeywell to generate electricity&#10;&gt; on customer site (degen). using natural gas. in doing so, i need your&#10;&gt; best fixed price forward gas price deal for 1, 3, 5, 7 and 10 years for&#10;&gt; annual/seasonal supply to microturbines to generate fixed kwh for&#10;&gt; customer. we have the opportunity to sell customer kwh &apos;s using&#10;&gt; microturbine or sell them turbines themselves. kwh deal must have limited/&#10;&gt; no risk forward gas price to make deal work. therein comes sempra energy&#10;&gt; gas trading, truly you.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; we are proposing installing 180 - 240 units across a large number of&#10;&gt; stores (60-100) in san diego.&#10;&gt; store number varies because of installation hurdles face at small percent.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; 673:<mail><row>673</row><date>2000/12/22</date><from>john.arnold@enron.com</from><to>slafontaine@globalp.com</to><subj>re: plants shut down and sell the energy</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>the market had to get to a price whereby these guys shut down. there is just &#10;not enough gas to allow everybody who wants to to burn it. the elasticity of &#10;demand is in the industrial sector. million dollar question is have we &#10;gotten to a high enough price whereby we end the year with gas in the ground &#10;and deliverability to meet a late cold snap. shutdown of processing, &#10;distillate and resid switching, loss of industrial load...maybe we have.&#10;good holidays,&#10;john&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;slafontaine@globalp.com on 12/22/2000 07:11:26 am&#10;to: slafontaine@globalp.com&#10;cc: &#10;subject: plants shut down and sell the energy&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;subject: plants shut down and sell the energy&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;plants shut down and sell the energy&#10;by peter behr&#10;washington post staff writer&#10;thursday, december 21, 2000; page e01&#10;kaiser aluminum corp. had planned to spend december making aluminum at its&#10;giant smelters in the pacific northwest, run by electricity from the&#10;bonneville power administration&apos;s columbia river dams. then it saw a better&#10;deal. with california desperate for power and electricity prices hitting&#10;unheard-of peaks, kaiser shut down its two u.s. smelters last week. it is&#10;selling the electricity it no longer needs -- for about 20 times what it&#10;pays bonneville under long-standing contracts.&#10;it is a measure of this winter&apos;s fuel crunch: some big industrial firms in&#10;energy-intensive sectors such as paper, fertilizers, metals and even&#10;oil-field operations can make more money by selling their electricity or&#10;natural gas than manufacturing their products. the shifts by such large&#10;industrial consumers of energy -- described as unprecedented by analysts --&#10;will free up more fuel for households and businesses this winter. but they&#10;also are sowing seeds of potential problems next year. shortages of aluminum&#10;and fertilizer, for example, are likely to give another upward jolt to&#10;consumer prices and further weaken the economy, analysts said.&#10;&quot;the fertilizer picture is particularly worrying us because we don&apos;t know&#10;what they&apos;re going to use to grow crops with,&quot; said david wyss, chief&#10;economist at standard &amp; poor&apos;s. some economists have recently increased&#10;their warnings about the damaging impact of this winter&apos;s heating bills on&#10;an already weakening economy. goldman sachs analysts last week estimated&#10;that gas heating bills will double this winter to more than $1,000 for a&#10;typical u.s. household.&#10;that and higher electricity prices will cost consumers $20 billion in higher&#10;energy costs compared with a year ago, they estimated, cutting the expected&#10;growth in the nation&apos;s economic output by one percentage point on an annual&#10;rate in the first three months of next year. &quot;overall, the recent energy&#10;price developments have thus added to the risk of a sharp economic&#10;slowdown,&quot; the goldman sachs report concluded. terra industries inc., in&#10;sioux city, iowa, has closed three of its six u.s. ammonia plants, which use&#10;natural gas as a main ingredient for fertilizer production. like kaiser, the&#10;company realized it would be much more profitable to stop production in&#10;december and sell the natural gas back to the market at current prices,&#10;which are much higher than the price terra was obligated to pay under its&#10;existing december supply contract, said mark rosenbury, chief administrative&#10;officer.&#10;&quot;we looked at these [current] prices and said, &apos;this is crazy,&apos; &quot; he said.&#10;terra hasn&apos;t disclosed the profit it will make selling its gas, but&#10;rosenbury said it would be &quot;substantial.&quot; in coming months, terra&apos;s good&#10;fortune could be reversed. it usually buys gas a month at a time, and the&#10;prices for january delivery most likely will be well above its break-even&#10;point. that would keep terra&apos;s plants closed, rosenbury said, but eliminate&#10;the opportunity to sell the natural gas at a profit. &quot;if this persists,&quot;&#10;rosenbury said, &quot;it&apos;s going to be a real problem.&quot;&#10;he estimates that out of a total annual u.s. production capacity of 18&#10;million tons of ammonia, about 4 million tons of production isn&apos;t operating&#10;now. &quot;could we be short of fertilizer next spring? it&apos;s possible that&#10;farmers will not have as much as they want,&quot; rosenbury said. royster-clark&#10;inc., a norfolk and new york city-based fertilizer manufacturer and&#10;distributor, has shut down its one plant in east dubuque, ill.,&#10;indefinitely, and 72 production workers will be laid off, beginning next&#10;month. the story is the same -- natural gas prices are too high to justify&#10;continued production. &quot;we believe it&apos;s likely this is a speculative bubble&#10;[in natural gas prices] that will burst and in a few weeks we&apos;ll be able to&#10;buy gas at a more reasonable price, but that remains to be seen,&quot; said paul&#10;m. murphy, the company&apos;s managing director for financial planning. a&#10;continuation of high natural gas prices would likely shrink production and&#10;raise fertilizer prices to a point that could affect farmers&apos; decisions to&#10;plant feed corn, he said. &quot;it&apos;s sticker shock.&quot;&#10;according to wyss, if this winter remains unusually cold and natural gas&#10;remains above $7 per million cubic feet -- double the level a year ago --&#10;farm products could rise significantly a year from now and into 2002. in the&#10;aluminum industry, several smaller producers have joined kaiser, the&#10;industry&apos;s no. 2 manufacturer, in closing down, noted lloyd o&apos;carroll, an&#10;analyst with bb&amp;t capital markets in richmond.&#10;aluminum production in november was 8.3 percent below that of november 1999,&#10;and december&apos;s production will be lower still, he said. &quot;we&apos;ll get more&#10;production cut announcements, i think,&quot; he said. a slowing in the u.s. and&#10;world economies next year could ease the impact of reduced aluminum&#10;supplies. &quot;but if the world economy doesn&apos;t fall completely apart, then&#10;[aluminum] prices are going to rise, and they could rise significantly more&#10;than the current forecast,&quot; he said. in kaiser&apos;s case, it&apos;s an open question&#10;how much of its electric windfall it will keep. kaiser is contractually&#10;entitled to buy electricity from bonneville at $22.50 a megawatt per hour,&#10;says spokesman scott lamb. that is the power it has sold back to bonneville&#10;for $550 a megawatt hour for december.&#10;but the bonneville authority is pressuring kaiser to use these and future&#10;profits from power resales to compensate employees at the shut-down plants,&#10;to invest in new electric generating capacity, or even to refund to&#10;bonneville&apos;s other customers, said bonneville spokesman ed mosey. kaiser and&#10;bonneville have negotiated a new power purchase deal to take effect after&#10;next october, but the power authority says it intends to reduce deliveries&#10;to kaiser if the company tries to pocket the electricity sale profits. &quot;out&#10;here, a deal is a deal, but it has to be a moral deal. there has to be an&#10;ethical dimension to this and we&apos;re not shy in trying to make sure they live&#10;up their advantage in having access to this publicly-owned power,&quot; mosey&#10;said.&#10;, 2000 the washington post company&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

the&#10;&gt; subject of the call is this: in order for us to pull off this deal, we&apos;ll&#10;&gt; need decision makers at the policy level to engage- throwing this back to&#10;&gt; legal is a downward spiral. i&apos;m not saying we don&apos;t need legal involved,&#10;&gt; but the direction must come from those that see the commercial picture.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; please provide the telephone numbers for the following people:&#10;&gt; edith kelly green&#10;&gt; graham smith&#10;&gt; mike golden&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; sincerely,&#10;&gt; jw&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

677:<mail><row>677</row><date>2000/12/20</date><from>john.arnold@enron.com</from><to>jennifer.fraser@enron.com</to><subj>re: apis</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>any idea what amount of switching in gas equivalents does the implied demand &#10;of resid equate to?&#10;&#10;&#10; &#10; &#10; &#10; from: jennifer fraser 12/20/2000 03:05 am&#10; &#10;&#10;to: john arnold/hou/ect@ect&#10;cc: &#10;subject: apis&#10;&#10;ja:&#10;see note on switching. it is hard to monitor the distiallte because any &#10;switching is being absorbed by the incessant arrival of european cargoes. we &#10;hope to have you guys some better numbers before the end of the week.&#10;&#10;---------------------- forwarded by jennifer fraser/hou/ect on 20/12/2000 &#10;09:00 ---------------------------&#10;&#10;&#10;alex mcleish@enron&#10;20/12/2000 02:40&#10;to: london, jennifer.fraser@enron.com, sarah mulholland/hou/ect@ect&#10;cc: &#10;subject: apis&#10;&#10;pira report attached - bit uninspired this week, like the stats.&#10;&#10;crude went back to the usual pattern and built 2 .4 mbbls, as opposed to an &#10;implied draw (excl spr) of 2 (although half of this in padd 5). perhaps &#10;surprisingly, runs were down again, but most of this was non-cdu, and &#10;gasoline bore the brunt of the output drop as a result. &#10;distillate demand, the main factor to watch, did fall, but not by much (240 &#10;kbd), and only another weak import showing prevented a build. the cold &#10;weather and switching are definitely having an impact, as this demand is well &#10;above last year&apos;s y2k inflated levels. most of the draw was in low sulphur &#10;material, but padd 1 still suffered a 500 kbbls drop in heating oil stocks. &#10;however, it does sems to be building up in padd 3.&#10;gasoline stocks did build, but interestingly only in blending components, not &#10;the finished material. evidence of high gas prices impacting on production? &#10;stocks rose in padd 1 by almost the same amount as they fell in padd 3. &#10;imports were very strong, however, at 500 kbd.&#10;again, the real shoker was resid - demand up 57% to 1600 kbd, an incredibly &#10;high number, and clear evidence (if repeated next week) of switching.&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

met with peter goebel and his team on the &#10;gss buy side, and participated in an experience enron tour, gerry has been &#10;unable to define an hp business proposition. the coordination between &#10;cashiola (short term initiative) morgridge (long term, 12-24 months) has &#10;remained unorganized. these initiatives need to be developed separately.&#10;&#10;&#10;clearly, the conversations with hp need to be elevated to a more senior &#10;level so ebs can work with hp decision makers who can move the relationship &#10;forward at a strategic level. as the relationship is developed at this &#10;strategic level, shorter term opportunities will crop up along the way. but &#10;gerry&apos;s short term plans will not be the focus of the ebs/hp relationship, &#10;rather a by-product. to facilitate this process of elevating the &#10;relationship, jennifer medcalf and i are following up with bill lovejoy and &#10;greg pyle. lovejoy&apos;s boss is dan sytsma, vp of hp&apos;s america&apos;s central &#10;region.&#10;&#10; enron utilizes temporary staffing services to satisfy=20&#10;staffing requirements throughout the company. for the past several months,=&#10; a=20&#10;project team, representing enron=01,s temporary staffing users, have resear=&#10;ched=20&#10;and evaluated alternative managed services programs to determine which sour=&#10;ce=20&#10;would best meet our current and future needs in terms of quality, performan=&#10;ce=20&#10;and cost containment objectives. the business unit implementation project=&#10;=20&#10;team members are:=20&#10;&#10;laurie koenig, operations management, ees&#10;carolyn vigne, administration, ee&amp;cc&#10;linda martin, accounting &amp; accounts payable, corporate&#10;beverly stephens, administration, ena&#10;norma hasenjager, human resources, et&amp;s&#10;peggy mccurley, administration, networks&#10;jane ellen weaver, enron broadband services&#10;paulette obrecht, legal, corporate&#10;george weber, gss&#10;&#10;in addition, eric merten (ebs), kathy cook (ee&amp;cc), carolyn gilley (ena),=&#10;=20&#10;larry dallman (corp/ap), and diane eckels (gss) were active members of the=&#10;=20&#10;selection project team.&#10;&#10;as a result of the team=01,s efforts, we are pleased to announce the beginn=&#10;ing=20&#10;of a strategic alliance with corestaff=01,s managed services group. this g=&#10;roup=20&#10;will function as a vendor-neutral management entity overseeing all staffing=&#10;=20&#10;vendors in the program scope. they will also provide a web based online=20&#10;technology tool that will enhance the ordering and reporting capabilities. =&#10;=20&#10;the goal of our alliance with corestaff is to make obtaining a temporary=20&#10;worker with the right skills and experience easier while protecting the bes=&#10;t=20&#10;interests of the organization.=20&#10;&#10;we plan to implement phase i of this improvement effective january 2, 2001.=&#10; =20&#10;this phase i of the implementation will encompass administrative/clerical=&#10;=20&#10;temporary workers at the houston locations only. if you currently have=20&#10;administrative/clerical temporary workers in your department, the enhanceme=&#10;nt=20&#10;will not affect their position. in an effort to preserve relationships, all=&#10;=20&#10;current staffing vendors will be invited to participate in this enhanced=20&#10;program. corestaff shares our commitment to minimize any disruptions in=20&#10;service during this transition.=20&#10;=20&#10;we expect to incorporate the administrative/clerical workers in omaha,=20&#10;seattle and portland in phase ii, which is scheduled for february, 2001. t=&#10;he=20&#10;scope and timing of any additional phases will be determined after these tw=&#10;o=20&#10;phases have been completed.&#10;&#10;realizing the impact that the temporary workforce has in business today, we=&#10;=20&#10;selected corestaff=01,s managed services group based on their exceptional=&#10;=20&#10;management team, commitment to quality service, and creative solutions to o=&#10;ur=20&#10;staffing needs. the relationship promises to offer enron a cost effective=&#10;=20&#10;and simple means for obtaining temporary employees.&#10;&#10;in the coming weeks, enron and corestaff=01,s managed services group will b=&#10;e=20&#10;communicating to enron=01,s administrative/clerical temporary staffing vend=&#10;ors=20&#10;about the new process. =20&#10;&#10;there are many benefits to this new managed services program, which are=20&#10;outlined on the attached page. more details on how to utilize corestaff=01=&#10;,s=20&#10;managed services program will be announced soon and meetings will be=20&#10;scheduled to demonstrate the reporting system and to meet the managed=20&#10;services team.&#10;&#10;what is managed services?&#10;&#10;corestaff=01,s managed services program includes:&#10;&#10;? vendor-neutral management model&#10;? equal distribution of staffing orders to all staffing partners&#10;? web-based application with online ordering, data capture and customized=&#10;=20&#10;reporting&#10;? benchmarking and performance measurement for continuous improvement&#10;? methodologies for accurate skill-matching and fulfillment efficiencies=20&#10;&#10;key benefits&#10;&#10;? more vendors working on each order from the outset =01) faster access to=&#10;=20&#10;available talent pools&#10;? standardized mark-ups and fees to manage costs more effectively&#10;? online access to requisition status for users=20&#10;? robust databases offering managers enhanced tracking and reporting of=20&#10;temporary usage and expenditures&#10;? standard and customized reporting capabilities -- online&#10;? tenured, experienced managed services team on-site to assist users in=20&#10;accessing web site, identifying usage trends, preparing specialized reports=&#10;,=20&#10;etc. =20&#10;&#10;corestaff/managed services/staffing&#10;&#10;joseph marsh =01) lead / operations (josephm@corestaff.com; 713-438-1400)&#10;amy binney, sharon b. sellers =01) operations&#10;cherri carbonara =01) marketing / communications&#10;cynthia duhon =01)staffing partner management&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

british trader sentenced to prison&#10;&#10;&#10;this could be you&#10;&#10;british trader sentenced to prison=20&#10;&#10; by jill lawless&#10; associated press writer&#10; tuesday, oct. 3, 2000; 2:07 p.m. edt&#10;&#10; london =01)=01) a futures trader who bet the wrong way on=&#10; u.s.&#10; unemployment figures, and destroyed a company in 92=20&#10;minutes, was&#10; sentenced tuesday to more than three years in jail.=20&#10;&#10; &quot;the position got worse and he was just numb,&quot; a defense=&#10;=20&#10;attorney said,&#10; comparing the debacle to a bad night at a roulette wheel.=&#10;=20&#10;&#10; stephen humphries, 25, formerly a trader at sussex future=&#10;s=20&#10;ltd., sank&#10; the company with losses of $1.1 million.=20&#10;&#10; &quot;during that afternoon of friday, aug. 6, 1999, during a=&#10;=20&#10;period of one&#10; hour, 32 minutes, the company&apos;s hard-earned reputation an=&#10;d=20&#10;value was&#10; destroyed at a stroke ... by the fraudulent trading=20&#10;activity of one man,&#10; stephen humphries,&quot; said prosecution lawyer martin hicks.=&#10;=20&#10;&#10; humphries pleaded guilty to one count of fraudulent=20&#10;trading. judge denis&#10; levy sentenced him to three years and nine months in=20&#10;prison.=20&#10;&#10; southwark crown court heard testimony that humphries ran =&#10;up=20&#10;the&#10; losses by trading futures contracts in government bonds,=&#10;=20&#10;and repeatedly&#10; lied to superiors about his trades.=20&#10;&#10; when worried colleagues left to summon the firm&apos;s senior=&#10;=20&#10;broker,&#10; humphries fled the building.=20&#10;&#10; after the huge one-day loss, the company&apos;s creditor banks=&#10;=20&#10;balked and a&#10; financial regulator was called in. sussex futures =01) wh=&#10;ich=20&#10;employed 70&#10; brokers =01) ceased trading three months later with losse=&#10;s of=20&#10;$3.4 million.=20&#10;&#10; the court was told that humphries&apos; trading losses began o=&#10;n=20&#10;the morning of&#10; aug. 6, wiping out two-thirds of his $25,000 trading=20&#10;deposit by lunchtime.&#10;&#10; the situation worsened at 1:30 p.m., when u.s. economic=&#10;=20&#10;figures were&#10; released showing no increase in the unemployment rate. th=&#10;e=20&#10;data made&#10; u.s. interest rates more likely to rise and reduced the=&#10;=20&#10;value of&#10; fixed-interest investments such as british government=20&#10;bonds.=20&#10;&#10; nonetheless, humphries continued to buy, in quantities th=&#10;at=20&#10;exceeded his&#10; trading ceiling. questioned by co-workers about the large=&#10;=20&#10;trades going&#10; through his account, humphries said he was in the process=&#10;=20&#10;of selling out.=20&#10;&#10; by the time he fled, he held more than 100 times his=20&#10;trading limit in futures.&#10;&#10; &quot;in the course of an afternoon ... you ruined not only yo=&#10;ur=20&#10;own career, but&#10; the career of many others and you caused a prosperous=20&#10;company, sussex&#10; futures limited, to go into liquidation, causing loss to=&#10;=20&#10;the company which&#10; trusted you and employed you,&quot; said the judge.=20&#10;&#10; defense lawyer simon ward said humphries had been under=&#10;=20&#10;intense&#10; financial pressure and was &quot;deeply sorry.&quot;=20&#10;&#10; he had lost a previous job when a trading company he work=&#10;ed=20&#10;for went&#10; under =01) also at the hands of a rogue trader.=20&#10;&#10; he had taken out large bank loans, amassed a substantial=&#10;=20&#10;credit-card debt&#10; and had borrowed from his father&apos;s life savings. he and h=&#10;is=20&#10;partner, with&#10; whom he had two children, had a third baby die, a blow th=&#10;at=20&#10;affected&#10; humphries&apos; judgment, ward said.=20&#10;&#10; &quot;this is a tragic and very upsetting case,&quot; said ward. &quot;h=&#10;e=20&#10;was 24, under&#10; intense financial and personal pressure and, in effect,=&#10;=20&#10;lost his head at the&#10; roulette table.&quot;=20&#10;&#10; , copyright 2000 the associated press=20&#10;&#10; back to the top=20&#10;&#10;</body></mail>
727:<mail><row>727</row><date>2000/11/30</date><from>jeff.youngflesh@enron.com</from><to>chaz.vaughan@enron.com,stephen.morse@enron.com</to><subj>ebs opp&apos;ty w/bmc</subj><cc>jennifer.medcalf@enron.com</cc><bcc>jennifer.medcalf@enron.com</bcc><body>chaz &amp;
