of bmc product.&#10;&#10;for example, ebs is poised to buy about $1 million worth of bmc software, but &#10;needs to show bmc a firm purchase commitment for about $3 million in total &#10;enron purchases from bmc. a way in which you could reach the $3 million mark &#10;with bmc; while also allowing the relationships between net works and bmc &#10;time to &quot;click&quot; might be this: ebs buys all $3 million worth of bmc &#10;software, but $1 million is used to actually take product now, and the other &#10;$2 million is used as a &quot;future purchases&quot; fund, in which ebs buys, but does &#10;not take immediate delivery of, the (remaining $2 million worth of) current &#10;software...&#10;&#10;then, future enron net works (and any other ene business unit) purchases of &#10;bmc software would be executed such that ebs is paid, and the software is &#10;delivered from/by bmc. that way, ebs gets its $2 million back, the other &#10;business units aren&apos;t spending any of today&apos;s dollars for product which they &#10;seem to have some concerns about (but they can get current/certified product &#10;when they need it in the future). in addition, you secure the business with &#10;bmc right now. i&apos;m sure you could also figure out how to account for the &#10;time value of money in this, so that there is further leverage advantage to &#10;you.&#10;&#10;if all else fails, you may wish to consider something like this...in the &#10;meantime, we will continue along the current path and keep you posted on &#10;progress.&#10;&#10;thanks,&#10;&#10;jeff&#10;&#10;jeff youngflesh&#10;director, business development&#10;global strategic sourcing&#10;enron corp.&#10;333 clay street, 11th floor&#10;houston, tx 77002&#10;t: 713-345-5968&#10;f: 713-646-2450&#10;c: 713-410-6716</body></mail>

731:<mail><row>731</row><date>1979/12/31</date><from>john.arnold@enron.com</from><to>tom.wilbeck@enron.com</to><subj>re: technical help for interviewing traders</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>in regards to gas:&#10;what signals do you for in determining your view?&#10; no right answer. some examples are strength or weakness in financial basis &#10;and index markets, customer flow, cash/futures spread, technical analysis, &#10;storage projections, price action, etc.&#10;what resources do you use to formulate a price view?&#10; goal is to see how much he analyzes the fundamentals of the market&#10; weather - does candidate look at weather models such as american, european, &#10;and canadian operational runs or does he just subscribe to a weather &#10;service&#10; storage - has he built an aga forecasting model or does he just wait for &#10;others to tell him projections&#10; production - has candidate dug into eia production data, company specific &#10;drilling results, or state specific (such as texas railroad commission &#10;reports)&#10; end of season storage number - has candidate built a longer term forecast &#10;of where we end up in storage. &#10;give example of complex transaction you&apos;ve structured for a customer.&#10;where is storage now relative to history? what is the highest and lowest &#10;level we&apos;ve been at in past 5 years?&#10;what are your short, medium, and long term views of gas market?&#10;what major basis changes have occured in the market over the past 5 years? &#10;what do you expect in the next 5?&#10;how should a storage operator decide whether or not to inject on any given &#10;day?&#10;&#10;in regards to derivatives in order of difficulty&#10;what are delta/gamma/theta?&#10;if you buy a put spread, is your delta positive, negative, or zero?&#10;is swap price equal to simple average of futures contracts?&#10;if interest rates go up what happens to option prices all else equal?&#10;what is the value of a european $1 call expiring in 12 months if &#10;corresponding futures are trading $5?&#10;what happens to delta of an option if volatility increase?&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;from: tom wilbeck/enron@enronxgate on 04/04/2001 11:20 am&#10;to: john arnold/hou/ect@ect&#10;cc: &#10;subject: re: technical help for interviewing traders&#10;&#10;john, &#10;thanks a million for your input.&#10;i was wondering if you could outline some good responses to these questions.&#10;&#10;with your interpretation of a good response, or points to consider, this will &#10;be a great resource for other interviewers.&#10;&#10;thanks again,&#10;&#10;tom wilbeck&#10;5-7536&#10;&#10; -----original message-----&#10;from: arnold, john &#10;sent: thursday, march 29, 2001 7:11 pm&#10;to: wilbeck, tom&#10;subject: re: technical help for interviewing traders&#10;&#10;in regards to gas:&#10;what signals do you for in determining your view?&#10;what resources do you use to formulate a price view?&#10;give example of complex transaction you&apos;ve structured for a customer.&#10;where is storage now relative to history? 735:<mail><row>735</row><date>2001/05/13</date><from>john.arnold@enron.com</from><to>david.forster@enron.com</to><subj>re:</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>david:&#10;do you have a simulation set up that will allow me to simulate trades by &#10;pushing a buy or sell button and will move the two way so i can try &#10;simulating actual market cicumstances?&#10;&#10;&#10;from: david forster/enron@enronxgate on 05/08/2001 09:55 am&#10;to: john arnold/hou/ect@ect&#10;cc: savita puthigai/enron@enronxgate &#10;subject: &#10;&#10;&#10;john,&#10;&#10;you might recall we spoke a few weeks ago about a system with more &#10;intelligence for out-of-hours trading than just leaving the products on last &#10;trade is mid.&#10;&#10;attached is a suggestion for how such a system might work. it builds on &#10;offset to last trade functionality.&#10;&#10;the simplified description is: it tracks two variables: intensity(speed) and &#10;bias (buy or sell emphasis). as intensity increases, the spread increases. &#10;as bias increases, the offset increases.&#10;&#10;i&apos;ll call later to see what you think of the idea.&#10;&#10;dave&#10;&#10; &#10;&#10;program criteria&#10;&#10;the formula which defines the trading decision-making program will need to &#10;work with several criteria/inputs/definitions. these might be:&#10;&#10;intensity (speed) - the average time between transaction attempts, regardless &#10;of whether they are buys or sells. measured as a moving average over the last &#10;[intensity factor] transactions by comparing the timestamp of the transaction &#10;tibco messages for the product.&#10;obviously, the lower the intensity calculation, the higher the transaction &#10;flow. therefore a high intensity number indicates low transaction flow.&#10;intensity factor - the number of transactions to be included in the moving &#10;average intensity calculation. a possible value for this might be [4].&#10;#buys - the number of buys which have occurred.&#10;#sells - the number of sells which have occured.&#10;transaction count - could be either #buys or #sells (whichever last occured).}&#10;buy offset - the offset value which will be applied if a buy occurs.&#10;sell offset - the offset value which will be applied if a sell occurs.&#10;offset reversion ratio (orr)- the amount by which the buy offset should be &#10;reduced if a sell occurs (or amount sell offset should be reduced if a buy &#10;occurs). a possible value for this might be [0.3]. if the application of the &#10;orr results in a reduction of less than 1, then the reduction shall be 1.&#10;transaction reversion ratio (trr)- the amount by which #buys should be &#10;reduced if a sell occurs (or amount #sells should be reduced if a buy &#10;occurs). a possible value for this might be [0.3]. if the application of the &#10;trr results in a reduction of less than 1, then the reduction shall be equal &#10;to 1.&#10;spread minimum - the minimum spread value allowed. a possible value for this &#10;might be [0.04]&#10;spread maximum - the maximum spread value allowed. a possible value for this &#10;might be [0.50]&#10;offset minimum - the minimum offset allowed for both buys and sells. a &#10;possible value for this might be [0].&#10;offset maximum -the maximum offset allowed for both buys and sells. a &#10;possible value for this might be [0.50]&#10;initial offset - the buy and sell offset used when the program is started&#10;initial spread - the spread used when the program is started&#10;spread-offset minimum - the minimum amount by which spread must exceed &#10;offset. prevents a possible arbitrage opportunity for the customer. a &#10;possible value for this might be [0.01]&#10;dead interval - the period of time which must pass before the program will &#10;recalculate the above criteria, if no transactions have taken place during &#10;the dead interval. a possible value for this might be [240] seconds.&#10;&#10;program outputs&#10;&#10;the program should output the following variables as a result of combining &#10;the above criteria in a user-defined formula:&#10;&#10;spread (integer) - as per current stack manager&#10;offset (integer) - as per current stack manager&#10;suspension (boolean) - whether or not the product should be suspended. &#10;normally &quot;false&quot;&#10;&#10;&#10;program interface and operation principles&#10;&#10;the user should be provided with a gui which will allow them to define a &#10;relationship among the above criteria, which will produce and apply the &#10;outputs to a particular product. this relationship would be defined with &#10;intensity formulas and transaction formulas. &#10;&#10;every time a transaction occurs, or a dead interval passes, the criteria will &#10;be recalculated and the user-defined formulas will be reviewed by the &#10;program. if a dead interval passes without any transactions taking place, &#10;then intensity = intensity +240 and #buys=#buys-trr and #sells=#sells-trr and &#10;buy offset = buy offset- orr and sell offset = sell offset - orr. &#10;&#10;if the user-defined formulas (see following) indicate that a change in spread &#10;should occur, then if the offset is zero (in the case of a trade occurring) &#10;or if no trade has occured (during the passing of a dead interval), the &#10;system shall perform a last trade is mid calculation around the last &#10;transaction, adjusting the buy and sell prices according to the new spread &#10;value.&#10;&#10;any adjustment to the spread shall respect the spread-offset minimum. if a &#10;reduction in the spread should violate the spread-offset minimum, then the &#10;buy offset (or sell offset, or both as appropriate) shall be reduced &#10;accordingly. similarly, if the offset is increased by a transaction formula &#10;to a level greater than the spread, the spread shall be increased to maintain &#10;the spread-offset minimum.&#10;&#10;gui/formulas example:&#10;&#10;constants&#10;intensity factor: [4]&#10;dead interval: [240]&#10;offset reversion ratio (orr): [0.3]&#10;transaction reversion ratio (trr): [0.3]&#10;spread minimum [0.04]&#10;spread maximum [0.50]&#10;offset minimum [0]&#10;offset maximum [0.49]&#10;spread-offset minimum [0.01]&#10;&#10; inputs outputs&#10;intensity formula&#10;formula # intensity spread offset suspension&#10;s1 &gt;220 -0.01 n/a f&#10;s2 &lt;30 +0.01 n/a f&#10;s3 &lt;10 +0.02 n/a f&#10;&#10;transaction formula&#10;formula # # transactions spread offset suspension&#10;v1 &lt;4 n/a -0.01 f&#10;v2 &gt;3 n/a +0.01 f&#10;v3 &gt;5 +0.01 +0.02 f&#10;v4 &gt;10 +0.02 +0.04 f&#10;v5 &gt;15 +0.04 +0.15 f&#10;v6 &gt;20 n/a n/a t&#10; &#10;note that #transactions would be #buys or #sells, as appropriate. note also &#10;that #buys and #sells are not intended to be an absolute count, but rather &#10;are a moving measure of the number of buys or sells which have recently &#10;occured.&#10;&#10;in this example, all constants and formulae are editable by the user through &#10;the gui.&#10;&#10;&#10;simulation&#10;&#10;obviously, if we want to proceed, we will want to conduct several simulations &#10;to prove concepts and evaluate responsiveness. however, to give some idea of &#10;how the above might work when a market starts to run in a particular &#10;direction, please see the attached:&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;additional features&#10;&#10;system notifications&#10;&#10;there should be two kinds of notifications for the robotrader, which will be &#10;similar to stack manager garbage checks: warning and failure levels for both &#10;offset and price. the warning levels will trigger a pager message. the &#10;failure levels will trigger a pager message and the product will be &#10;automatically suspended. the price checks will be against prices input by the &#10;trader (not relative price movements, but actual price). there should be both &#10;maximum and minimum price checks (e.g. gas is trading at $5.50. the &#10;notification levels could be $8 at the top end and $2 at the bottom end). &#10;offset checks will only be against a maximum value.&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;dave&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

753:<mail><row>753</row><date>2000/12/12</date><from>russell.dyk@enron.com</from><to>john.arnold@enron.com</to><subj>lng to california</subj><cc>jennifer.fraser@enron.com</cc><bcc>jennifer.fraser@enron.com</bcc><body>john,&#10;following up on yesterday, there are two additional considerations. &#10;&#10;first, with regard to the idea of curtailing gas input at the topock &#10;liquefaction plant, the pipeline bottleneck is actually downstream of the &#10;plant, so that wouldn&apos;t help. &#10;&#10;second, it seems there are more of these &quot;portable pipeline&quot; units floating &#10;around than i thought. besides the inoperable unit in amarillo, both transgas &#10;(in massachusetts) and minnigasco may have at least one. moreover, pg&amp;e has &#10;one at the end of a long lateral line on its system just south of sacramento. &#10;apparently it uses it mostly to augment linepack. the specs of that unit are &#10;about 4 times higher than the amarillo one: it puts out 400,000 cubic &#10;feet/hour (about 9.6 mmcf/d or almost one contract) at 150 psi. as i said &#10;yesterday, these units are the only way that you could get gas into the &#10;pipeline system in california. &#10;&#10;this information i got from jeff beale, who runs ch-iv, a small-scale lng &#10;consultant. he said that he&apos;d had some similar calls about lng, and also that &#10;he&apos;d be willing to help enron source equipment if we were really interested &#10;in looking further into transporting lng into california. &#10;&#10;assuming that we could get a few &quot;portable pipelines&quot; and some trucks, there &#10;are five liquefaction plants that could most conveniently supply lng:&#10;&#10;location owner liquefaction capacity (gal/day) capacity (mmcf/d) storage &#10;(gal) storage (mmcf)&#10;topock, az elpaso/alt 90,000 7.4 100,000 8.2&#10;laplata, co williams 20,000 1.64 100,000 8.2&#10;sacramento 57,600 4.72 132,000 10.8&#10;labarge, wy exxon 60,000 4.92 &#10;evanston, wy amoco 95,000 7.8 100,000 8.2&#10;&#10;totals 26.48&#10;&#10;whether these plants have spare lng to sell us is another question. the &#10;sacramento plant, which i mentioned yesterday, is supposedly dedicated to &#10;providing methane for laboratory purposes. the others may have contracts with &#10;lng fleet owners. &#10;&#10;i&apos;ll check back with you later today about the outcome of your meeting. </body></mail>

in the past that the&#10;&gt;organization said violated its ethical code.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; rabbi zimmerman, president of hebrew union college-jewish&#10;&gt;institute of learning, where he had been considered a charismatic&#10;&gt;and innovative leader, quit that post on monday, after the central&#10;&gt;conference of american rabbis suspended his rabbinical functions&#10;&gt;for at least two years, college and conference officials said.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; in a statement, the college said the suspension followed an&#10;&gt;investigation by the conference into &quot;personal relationships&quot; of&#10;&gt;rabbi zimmerman, which it did not specify other than to say that&#10;&gt;they predated his appointment as president in january 1996. rabbi&#10;&gt;zimmerman was the seventh president of the college, which was&#10;&gt;founded in 1875.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; rabbi paul j. menitoff, the conference&apos;s executive vice president,&#10;&gt;said its board approved the penalty on monday, based on a&#10;&gt;recommendation by its ethics committee, which looks into complaints&#10;&gt;about the conference&apos;s 1,700 members.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; rabbi menitoff said that conference rules prevented him from&#10;&gt;discussing the case but that the board decided rabbi zimmerman had&#10;&gt;violated a part of the ethics code, paragraph 2a, which deals with&#10;&gt;sexual conduct.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; it is included in the section of the code on &quot;personal&#10;&gt;responsibility,&quot; which covers such matters as family life, personal&#10;&gt;honesty and finances. it calls on rabbis &quot;to be scrupulous in&#10;&gt;avoiding even the appearance of sexual misconduct, whether by&#10;&gt;taking advantage of our position with those weaker than ourselves&#10;&gt;or dependent on us or succumbing to the temptations of willing&#10;&gt;adults.&quot;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; hebrew union, which trains men and women as rabbis and cantors and&#10;&gt;in other graduate and professional fields, has 1,500 students on&#10;&gt;campuses in cincinnati, los angeles, new york and jerusalem. before&#10;&gt;becoming president, rabbi zimmerman, 58, was senior rabbi of temple&#10;&gt;emanu-el in dallas from 1985 to 1995, and senior rabbi at central&#10;&gt;synagogue in new york, from 1972 to 1985. he is married and has&#10;&gt;four children. from 1993 to 1995, he was also the conference&apos;s&#10;&gt;president.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; rabbi zimmerman&apos;s resignation was first reported yesterday in the&#10;&gt;cincinnati enquirer and the dallas morning news.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; efforts to reach him through the college and its officials were&#10;&gt;unsuccessful. the college said it appointed its provost, norman&#10;&gt;cohen, as acting president and would search for a permanent&#10;&gt;replacement.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; rabbi menitoff said the conference followed &quot;the same process that&#10;&gt;we&apos;d follow with any rabbi in the conference in similar&#10;&gt;circumstances.&quot; he said complaints against a rabbi are referred to&#10;&gt;and investigated by the ethics committee. depending on that&#10;&gt;committee&apos;s findings, the conference may dismiss the complaint,&#10;&gt;privately reprimand or publicly censure a rabbi or suspendn or&#10;&gt;expel a rabbi.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; rabbi menitoff said the decision to suspend rabbi zimmerman was&#10;&gt;&quot;very difficult and painful for everyone involved.&quot;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; rabbi eric h. yoffie, president of the union of american hebrew&#10;&gt;congregations, the reform movement&apos;s synagogue organization, said&#10;&gt;rabbi zimmerman did not contest the findings or the judgment&#10;&gt;against him but responded to the decision &quot;with great dignity.&quot;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; rabbi yoffie said that during his tenure as president, rabbi&#10;&gt;zimmerman added younger scholars to the faculty and expanded the&#10;&gt;college&apos;s los angeles branch so much that it will begin ordaining&#10;&gt;rabbis in 2002.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; another member of the conference, rabbi a. james rudin, emeritus&#10;&gt;director of interreligious affairs at the american jewish&#10;&gt;committee, said rabbi zimmerman&apos;s resignation was &quot;a real loss&quot; and&#10;&gt;&quot;a shock to the movement.&quot;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; hebrew union&apos;s chairman, burton lehman, praised rabbi zimmerman as&#10;&gt;&quot;a great, great leader.&quot; mr. lehman said that rabbi zimmerman&apos;s&#10;&gt;resignation would &quot;have an impact&quot; but that the college was strong.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; &quot;transitionally, we&apos;ll be fine,&quot; mr. lehman said. &quot;we have a&#10;&gt;strong faculty that will carry this institution through this&#10;&gt;tribulation.&quot;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;the new york times on the web&#10;&gt;http://www.nytimes.com&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;/-----------------------------------------------------------------\&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;visit nytimes.com for complete access to the&#10;&gt;most authoritative news coverage on the web,&#10;&gt;updated throughout the day.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;become a member today! it&apos;s free!&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;http://www.nytimes.com?eta&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;\-----------------------------------------------------------------/&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;how to advertise&#10;&gt;---------------------------------&#10;&gt;for information on advertising in e-mail newsletters&#10;&gt;or other creative advertising opportunities with the&#10;&gt;new york times on the web, please contact alyson&#10;&gt;racer at alyson@nytimes.com or visit our online media&#10;&gt;kit at http://www.nytimes.com/adinfo&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;for general information about nytimes.com, write to&#10;&gt;help@nytimes.com.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt;copyright 2000 the new york times company</body></mail>

760:<mail><row>760</row><date>2000/12/11</date><from>russell.dyk@enron.com</from><to>john.arnold@enron.com</to><subj>lng on the road</subj><cc>jennifer.fraser@enron.com</cc><bcc>jennifer.fraser@enron.com</bcc><body>re: trucking lng to california - &#10;&#10;the short answer is that trucking lng to california is not a feasible option &#10;for endusers other than companies with lng-fueled vehicle fleets. there are a &#10;couple of reasons for this. &#10;&#10;first, california has a relative abundance of lng fueling stations but only &#10;two plants capable of regasification. one serves borrego springs, a small, &#10;affluent desert community near san diego. the other is dedicated to military &#10;and industrial supply near sacramento. i spoke this morning to applied lng &#10;technologies, which is based in amarillo and has the second largest lng truck &#10;fleet (after transgas in massachusetts). it shouldn&apos;t be a surprise that i &#10;was not the first to call regarding this question. while alt&apos;s fleet is &#10;operating at capacity - trucking lng from liquefaction plants in wyoming and &#10;topock, arizona - it&apos;s serving its normal fleet customers in southern &#10;california and nevada, and arizona. the topock, az plant is owned jointly by &#10;alt and el paso, and receives gas from el paso for liquefaction and &#10;subsequent loading onto trucks.&#10;&#10;second, lng trucks, unlike lng tankers, carry an extremely small volume. the &#10;average truck carries 10,000 gallons of lng, which translates roughly into &#10;820,000 cubic feet. alt has about 23 vehicles so potentially one could &#10;deliver 18.8 mmcf. however, these trucks don&apos;t regasify lng, they merely &#10;transfer it into storage. &#10;&#10;the only really viable option for putting gas into the pipeline system would &#10;be a portable pipeline unit, of which alt has the only one (it&apos;s under &#10;repair). it can deliver high pressure gas at 1800 cubic feet/minute (2.6 &#10;mmcf/day if it runs 24 hours). it has connections for two lng trucks at a &#10;time - one live and one backup, so it can operate continuously. in the past, &#10;alt has used the unit to cover industrials who had a supply outage for some &#10;reason. &#10;&#10;i&apos;m going to continue gathering info on domestic lng peakshaving plants, etc. &#10;i think the opportunity may lie more in future, more strategically located &#10;peakshaving plants rather than lng trucking arbitrage. &#10;&#10;please let me know if you have specific questions.&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

capacity requirements for mbps, and burst potential.&#10;ip transit - capacity requirements and current contract usage for internet &#10;transit. kinkos.com in particular has a high potential for ip transit &#10;capacity.&#10;storage - as the hubs and branch numbers grow, there may be a need for &#10;managed storage. enron&apos;s solution will reduce, or eliminate the need to buy &#10;storage devices. mike rabon would like to speak with someone at kinko&apos;s about &#10;your storage strategy and growth.&#10;collocation - there is a substantial opportunity for enron to provide the &#10;actual space to be used for the hubs, as well as the ip transport from the &#10;hubs.&#10;interactive video - enron&apos;s ipnet connect product will allow high quality &#10;h.323 video conferencing at bandwidths well above 768k. utilizing the enron &#10;ipnet connect network installed to branches can allow video costs to be &#10;significantly reduced, and allow much higher video quality. enron&apos;s &#10;utilization of ip precedence will allow business traffic, internet traffic &#10;and video traffic to traverse the same network. mike rabon would like to &#10;speak to the video conferencing product manager.&#10;risk management - 819:<mail><row>819</row><date>2000/11/14</date><from>peter.berzins@enron.com</from><to>david.forster@enron.com,john.arnold@enron.com,dutch.quigley@enron.com</to><subj>otc ng price book trades</subj><cc>torrey.moorer@enron.com</cc><bcc>torrey.moorer@enron.com</bcc><body>the eol reporting database treats any distinct deal number as a separate &#10;unique deal. an example would be a deal done with kukui inc. on november &#10;8th, 2000. it is booked as deal numbers q86409.1, q86409.2, q86409.3, and &#10;q86409.4. these are four separate and unique deal numbers and therefore &#10;count as a total of four deals. &#10;&#10;we understand that the trade desk may consider the deal in this example as &#10;just one large deal with 4 different parts. unfortunately, the eol &#10;reporting database has no way of telling whether or not these types of deals &#10;are distinct different deals or part of one larger deal. since this &#10;currently can not be known, the eol reporting database uses the most &#10;conservative approach and counts them all as individual deals. this results &#10;in a higher otc deal count and thus a lower eol percentage of all deals.&#10;&#10;if you have any further questions , please don&apos;t hesitate to ask.&#10;&#10;pete berzins&#10;x57597&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

hi bruce,&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; i have attached a document detailing the status of microsoft&#10;&gt; certification. we have also summarized our windows 2000 development and&#10;&gt; certification methodology which is actually a two-phase approach. the&#10;&gt; most critical phase, which ensures win2k compatibility and support and&#10;&gt; includes customer testing, has been completed. the win2k agents are ga&#10;&gt; for both control-m (scheduling) and control-sa (security).&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; the next phase, which is also a key element of our development strategy,&#10;&gt; is to insure the products meet the certification requirements for&#10;&gt; microsoft win2k. this phase follows the win2k initial release as ms&#10;&gt; certification focuses on meeting certain microsoft standards and not the&#10;&gt; application&apos;s functionality - ability to work correctly in the control-m&#10;&gt; environment.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; microsoft certification does not necessarily guarantee the performance of&#10;&gt; the application. it is my understanding that one of the reasons control-m&#10;&gt; is being considered as a replacement for sys*admiral is due to the&#10;&gt; problems you are experiencing with their ms certified release.&#10;&gt;&#10;&gt; earlier this year we met with philippe bibi and reviewed bmc&apos;s win2k&#10;&gt; development plans. would it be helpful to set up a similar meeting with&#10;&gt; &gt; to: rob hallberg (e-mail)&#10;&gt; &gt; subject: fw: recap&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; rob, will you please forward this to larry.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; larry, below is the recap we talked about.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; recap:&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; there were 2 outstanding issues.&#10;&gt; &gt; 1) new day process running 2-5 hrs.&#10;&gt; &gt; 2) jobs not running, they were all in blue or white status.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; issue number 1 was resolved the day before i arrived by tech support&#10;&gt; &gt; working with rusty. solution was to increase the oracle db from 50mg&#10;&gt; to&#10;&gt; &gt; 300mg. also the log &amp; stat files were extremely small. these files&#10;&gt; were&#10;&gt; &gt; cleaned out by rusty, however were never increased or set to truncate&#10;&gt; in&#10;&gt; &gt; oracle. they will fill up again. these files need to be set to&#10;&gt; truncate&#10;&gt; &gt; by the oracle dba or run a set of daily utilities to clean those&#10;&gt; files.&#10;&gt; &gt; we will send a draft of those utilities to be incorporated into the&#10;&gt; daily&#10;&gt; &gt; schedule.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; issue number 2 - according to a diagnostic report the agent machine&#10;&gt; lost&#10;&gt; &gt; connection with the nis server for a greater period of time than what&#10;&gt; the&#10;&gt; &gt; default settings were set. the agent is set to retry every 120&#10;&gt; seconds up&#10;&gt; &gt; to 12 times. after this period, manual activation is required. i&#10;&gt; signed&#10;&gt; &gt; on as ctmagent user and ran ag_menu. ran option 2 which showed the&#10;&gt; nis as&#10;&gt; &gt; down. i then signed on as the control-m user and ran ctm_menu.&#10;&gt; selected&#10;&gt; &gt; 7 - agent status, selected 2 - list all agent platforms unavailable.&#10;&gt; &gt; agent on bmc was in unavailable status. next selected option 3 -&#10;&gt; change&#10;&gt; &gt; agent platform to available status. after doing that, all the jobs&#10;&gt; turned&#10;&gt; &gt; to gray status and started running.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; cleaned up 2 erroneous agent names defined to control-m/server.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; i also ran a trouble shooting report which produced a file&#10;&gt; &gt; (/var/home/ctlm00/report.1116001128) from this file we could tell&#10;&gt; when&#10;&gt; &gt; the log filed filled up and when the agent stopped.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; i set up 500 jobs to run daily on bmc with multiple dependencies.&#10;&gt; all&#10;&gt; ran&#10;&gt; &gt; ok.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; i set up aprox. another 150 cyclic jobs with dependencies to run on&#10;&gt; &gt; ocsdev-1. they failed due to not using the correct owner. rusty&#10;&gt; knows&#10;&gt; &gt; what the correct owner should be. i believed i used ctlm00.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; new day process ran for approx. 12 mins.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; right before leaving rusty ran a clean_db script, which resulted in&#10;&gt; &gt; cleaning out the entire database. fortunately by design, we were&#10;&gt; able&#10;&gt; to&#10;&gt; &gt; demonstrate the recoverability by uploading the tables from ecs to&#10;&gt; the&#10;&gt; &gt; control-m server. in less than 5 minutes all was ok.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; when i left there were approx. 900 jobs running. of those approx.&#10;&gt; 400&#10;&gt; &gt; jobs were running cyclic, every 2 minutes. which meant on a daily&#10;&gt; basis&#10;&gt; &gt; approx. 14,500 jobs ran per day.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; larry, i know you asked for some type of hardware recommendations.&#10;&gt; these&#10;&gt; &gt; is something that&apos;s very subjective. as with almost any software the&#10;&gt; more&#10;&gt; &gt; memory and faster cpu the better. to do this correctly, we should&#10;&gt; have&#10;&gt; &gt; our professional services come in and do some type of assessment of&#10;&gt; your&#10;&gt; &gt; environment and the direction your heading. how many jobs per day,&#10;&gt; today,&#10;&gt; &gt; near future, etc.... how many users of ecs? how many servers?&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; in your test environment you should be able to run 2000 jobs without&#10;&gt; a&#10;&gt; &gt; major problem. your ecs nt box is on the small size, at least in the&#10;&gt; &gt; memory area. so your responses might not be as fast as desired.&#10;&gt; please&#10;&gt; &gt; remember the out of the box default settings are not tuned to run a&#10;&gt; large&#10;&gt; &gt; number of jobs. therefore database tuning is always recommended.&#10;&gt; these&#10;&gt; &gt; tuning recommendations are provided by professional services.&#10;&gt; &gt;&#10;&gt; &gt; 863:<mail><row>863</row><date>2000/10/24</date><from>john.arnold@enron.com</from><to>russell.dyk@enron.com</to><subj>re: csfb columbia/appalachia hedging deal</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>certainly encourage csfp to transact all volumes with us. if they shop the &#10;deal, everyone will front-run the volumes and they won&apos;t get a good price on &#10;the deal. &#10;financial deals settle 5 days after the index has been published. physical &#10;deals settle much later. my understanding is this is a financial deal.&#10;&#10;&#10; &#10; &#10; &#10; from: russell dyk @ enron 10/23/2000 12:43 pm&#10; &#10;&#10;to: paul radous/corp/enron@enron&#10;cc: per sekse/ny/ect@ect, caroline abramo/corp/enron@enron, john &#10;arnold/hou/ect@ect, sara shackleton/hou/ect@ect, william s &#10;bradford/hou/ect@ect &#10;subject: csfb columbia/appalachia hedging deal&#10;&#10;the new york office has been speaking to credit suisse first boston for &#10;roughly 6 months about a producer hedging deal that is part of a strucutured &#10;deal they&apos;re putting together. it now looks as if it will get done in the &#10;next 3 weeks-1 month so we want to get all the necessary credit issues taken &#10;care of. &#10;&#10;in brief, the deal is a fixed price one, basis tco (67% of the volumes) and &#10;cng (33%) with a fixed price nymex component as well. it will settle against &#10;the inside ferc indices for both locations. the term of the deal is from &#10;december, 2000 to december 2012. the volumes decline throughout the term from &#10;roughly 22,000 mmbtu/d to 13,000 mmbtu/d. the average daily nominal volume is &#10;17,000 mmbtu/d. as i understand it, these volumes are about 65% of the &#10;producers&apos; total volumes. i&apos;ve attached a spreadsheet to this message with &#10;more details. &#10;&#10;there are a couple of contractual and credit issues that csfb wants to &#10;clarify. &#10;&#10;first, there is a question of the monthly cash settlement. csfb would like &#10;payment to take place on the fifteenth of the month following the date both &#10;the floating and fixed prices are known. as i understand it, for the &#10;december settlement, which would be known in early december, cash payment &#10;would take place on february 15, 2000. &#10;&#10;second, there is a question of a parent guarantee from enron corp. &#10;apparently, there is an existing credit arrangement in place between ena and &#10;credit suisse first boston international - the same counterparty that we &#10;would be dealing with here - that has a $15 million guarantee from enron &#10;corp. csfb would like to increase this guarantee to at least $100 million. &#10;(csfb already has an unlimited guarantee from enron corp. for a deal they&apos;ve &#10;done with us in europe so in their opinion it should not be an issue). &#10;&#10; there is another minor issue involving centralizing credit discussions with &#10;the aim of securing a similar credit arrangement for csfb&apos;s dealings with &#10;enroncredit.com - which may be an issue for london rather than houston. &#10;however, csfb agreed that this was a secondary issue in relation to this &#10;transaction.&#10;&#10;csfb would like to do the entire deal through us, rather than having to split &#10;it among one or more counterparties. per, caroline abramo, and i are meeting &#10;with paul tomorrow to discuss various credit issues, including this one. &#10;ideally, csfb would like to have a good idea of where they stand by the end &#10;of this week. &#10;&#10;please let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.&#10;&#10;regards,&#10;russ&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;</body></mail>

first, in gas, you can play the seasonality &#10;game. does anybody want to buy m/n at 1 back. no, of course not. but in &#10;crude, m/n at .10 back is normal. definitely a game as you try to keep month &#10;on month spreads somewhat within reason while preserving year on year spreads &#10;and creating equilibrium for where cal 2 on back hedging and spec demand is. &#10;that&apos;s why cal 2 is as high as it is. &#10;when was the last time the most bullish part of the nat gas curve was prompt &#10;month. i can&apos;t remember w/o looking at charts. it&apos;s always the mentality &#10;of: if it&apos;s tight now what about july or what about winter. i think that&apos;s &#10;why the winter spreads are a piece. the z/f/g fly is interesting. i think &#10;z/f can and will settle backw. just a 928:<mail><row>928</row><date>2000/10/06</date><from>john.arnold@enron.com</from><to>adam.r.bayer@vanderbilt.edu</to><subj>re: thank you for dinner last night</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>adam:&#10;good question. the exchange, nymex, and i, enron online, offer a nearly &#10;identical product. the fight is over which execution model is superior. i &#10;would argue that technology will make open outcry exchanges extinct. it&apos;s &#10;happened in europe already. the largest commodity exchange in europe, the &#10;liffe, went with a parallel electronic system to open outcry. within weeks, &#10;the floor was deserted and virtually all trading occurred electronically. i &#10;still trade on the exchange because we have credit issues with individuals &#10;and certain hedge funds that limit the trading we can do with them direct. &#10;the exchange still provides a credit intermediation function that is useful. &#10;it is certainly an issue that we are trying to address. &#10;john&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&quot;bayer, adam ryan&quot; &lt;adam.r.bayer@vanderbilt.edu&gt; on 10/03/2000 01:23:01 pm&#10;to: john.arnold@enron.com&#10;cc: &#10;subject: thank you for dinner last night&#10;&#10;&#10;dear mr. arnold,&#10;&#10; it was nice to meet you yesterday at the&#10;information session. thank you for the dinner last night.&#10;i had a great time getting to know enron and its people in&#10;a more relaxed setting.&#10;&#10; during out conversation yesterday, i was confused&#10;about a point you made. you stated that you spent most of&#10;your time on the phone with traders in new york. when&#10;you talk to the traders, do you try to steer them towards&#10;enron online, or are you doing trading outside of enron&#10;online? priority. i am willing to accept some of the credit risk &#10;exposure as a cost of doing business. bill understands his role as an &#10;independent in the market and performs the right risk/reward trades for &#10;someone with finite capital. i place very high confidence in bill not &#10;conducting high risk trades. having said that, we certainly need to monitor &#10;his credit exposure and continue to require lc&apos;s. just understand that he is &#10;at a different level of sophistication that any other non-investment grade &#10;counterparty.&#10;&#10;i understand there was some concern in regards to the transco z6 spread &#10;option he traded. he was absolutely right about the valuation and we, on the &#10;trading desk, knew it as well. there are a couple isolated products that &#10;enron does not do a good job of valuing because of systems limtations. this &#10;was one product. our spread options are booked in excel using option pricing &#10;models created by the research group. the problem with these models is that &#10;they are strictly theoretical and don&apos;t take into account gas fundamental &#10;price limitations. for instance, it is less probable, though not impossible, &#10;for a transport spread from a production area to a market area to go within &#10;variable cost than the models predict. thus it is necessary to apply a &#10;correlation skew curve on top of the overlying correlation used. obviously, &#10;we have this function in our pricing models. i was not aware this &#10;methodology had not been transferred to the valuation models. this has since &#10;been changed. fortunately these incidents tend to be extremely rare as very &#10;few non-investment grade companies trade these types of products. &#10;&#10;finally, on friday bill wanted to do a trade that reduced his exposure to &#10;enron. i gave mike maggi the go ahead to do the trade without consulting &#10;credit. i do not believe that i acted out of line in approving this trade &#10;considering the circumstances. if you believe differently, please advise.&#10;thanks, &#10;john</body></mail>

965:<mail><row>965</row><date>2000/09/26</date><from>john.arnold@enron.com</from><to>frank.hayden@enron.com</to><subj>re: stress test</subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>i&apos;m not sure what is happening on my position. it may have to do with how &#10;you shaped the forward vol and price curves at each level. my var is so &#10;dependent on spread levels and vols that a small change in the jan vols could &#10;produce that effect. &#10;the results certainly provide evidence of a need for higher var going into &#10;the winter.&#10;john&#10;&#10;&#10; &#10; enron north america corp.&#10; &#10; from: frank hayden @ enron 09/15/2000 06:32 pm&#10; &#10;&#10;to: john j lavorato/corp/enron@enron, john arnold/hou/ect@ect&#10;cc: vladimir gorny/hou/ect@ect, sunil dalal/corp/enron@enron &#10;subject: stress test&#10;&#10;the below file shows the results of the two stress test requested. under the &#10;$7 dollar stress, nymex curve was shifted to $7 dollars with all other price &#10;curves proportionally shifted. under the $9 dollar test, not only were the &#10;price curves shifted, but volatilites were stressed as well with nymex &#10;volatility going to 100% and all other vol locations being raised accordingly.&#10;&#10;&#10;key findings include:&#10;$7 dollar stress only raised var by 79% &#10;$9 dollar stress raised var by 134% &#10;&#10; &#10;&#10;it is interesting to note that with the seven dollar stress, var on the &#10;financial desk actually decreased. this would seem to imply that up to the &#10;seven dollar strike, the financial desk is long gamma (which overall reduces &#10;risk). but between the seven dollar and nine dollar strike, it appears that &#10;the desk becomes short gamma, thereby acceralatering the amount of risk and &#10;increasing var by 74%. does this make sense or is something else happening?&#10;&#10;frank&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;&#10;---------------------- forwarded by frank hayden/corp/enron on 09/15/2000 &#10;03:43 pm ---------------------------&#10; 989:<mail><row>989</row><date>2000/09/15</date><from>john.arnold@enron.com</from><to>david.forster@enron.com</to><subj></subj><cc></cc><bcc></bcc><body>dave:&#10;a couple things about the limit orders:&#10;&#10;1: when a customer opens up the limit order box, i think the time open &#10;should default to 12 hours. we want the orders open as long as possible. &#10;now, it is more work to keep the order open for 12 hours than for 1 hour. &#10;traditionally, limit orders are a day order, good for the entire trading &#10;session unless specified otherwise. &#10;&#10;2. today pete had 13,000/ day on his bid because he was hit for small size. &#10;when i tried to place a limit order, the quantity had to be in 5,000 &#10;increments of 13,000 (i.e. 3000, 8000, 18000...). i could not overwrite the &#10;quantity to be 15,000. &#10;&#10;3. everytime a limit order is placed, an error message occurs on the system &#10;saying error trade, price not available.&#10;&#10;4. is there a way to modify a limit order, such as changing the price, &#10;without canceling it and resubmitting a new one? if not, this would be a &#10;valuable feature.&#10;&#10;thx,&#10;john</body></mail>
